Best regards,
Mr. Schmeding
ChemWorld Operations

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello James,                    I am looking for a 250 metric tonne shipment of Alchohol from Tanjung Kelang (PJ) to Benin (CI). Could you give me an indication of freight costs, and is laytime negotiable beyond 45 days?                    Regards,                    Jean
Email 2:
Dear Jean,                       This is in reply to your recent enquiry regarding a shipment from Benin to
Singapore, of 250 metric tonnes of alchohol. Following our discussions, and in order to ascertain your full requirement,
we shall now provide you with a quote for your consideration.                       The following details have been noted in your enquiry:

From: Benin to Singapore (DP)           Loading port: Cotonou

Details of the cargo: 250 tonnes of alchohol

Delivery instructions: Container packed and ready at loading port. The client has also agreed to pay all applicable terminal fees. The client requires
the cargo to be placed on 24 hours notice, and delivery within 1 week of loading.


Tare: 7.5 tonnes
95.0 Net Gross wt - 7.5
                  Note: Lay time negotiable for both sides; Delivery in Singapore
Email 3:
Dear Jean,                      On a previous message, you have kindly quoted us as follows:     Carrier Cost: $6.600 + Insurance: $0.850 + Terminal Handling: $800 = $7,250

We understand that the above rate is applicable to a shipment of Alchohol from Benin to Singapore, with a loading port of Cotonou, and a
shipping date of 05/12/05. The above container includes all transport insurance, inclusive of war and strike.

Should you require any further assistance, or require any further details, please feel free to contact us at any time.                       Thank you,                    James
output_text:
From: jean.dupont@trading.com
To: james.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Freight Quote Request - Alcohol Shipment PJ to Benin
Timestamp: 2005-12-01 09:30
Body: Hello James,

I am looking for a 250 metric tonne shipment of Alcohol from Tanjung Kelang (PJ) to Benin (CI). Could you give me an indication of freight costs, and is laytime negotiable beyond 45 days?

Regards,
Jean

---

From: james.smith@shipping.com
To: jean.dupont@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Alcohol Shipment PJ to Benin
Timestamp: 2005-12-02 14:15
Body: Dear Jean,

Thank you for your enquiry regarding the shipment of 250 metric tonnes of alcohol. Please note that I understand the route to be from Cotonou, Benin to Singapore (DP).

I've noted the following specifications:
- Loading port: Cotonou
- Discharge port: Singapore
- Cargo: 250 tonnes of alcohol
- Container packed and ready at loading port
- Terminal fees to be paid by client
- 24 hours notice required
- Delivery within 1 week of loading
- Tare: 7.5 tonnes
- Net Gross weight: 95.0 - 7.5

Lay time is indeed negotiable for both parties.

I will prepare a detailed quote based on these specifications.

Best regards,
James

---

From: james.smith@shipping.com
To: jean.dupont@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Alcohol Shipment PJ to Benin
Timestamp: 2005-12-03 10:45
Body: Dear Jean,

I am pleased to provide you with the following quote breakdown:

Carrier Cost: $6,600
Insurance: $850
Terminal Handling: $800
Total: $7,250

This rate applies to your shipment of alcohol from Benin to Singapore, loading at Cotonou, with a shipping date of December 5th, 2005. The quote includes full transport insurance, including war and strike coverage.

Please let me know if you need any clarification or additional information.

Best regards,
James

#### The Nature of Viruses

A virus is a type of computer program, analogous to a self-replicating macro in a word processing program. A virus, once entered into a computer, takes control and executes a program that produces copies of itself. The advantage to a virus over a macro is that a virus is more difficult to detect and may be attached to legitimate files, in order to pass inspection. In other words, a virus is not usually flagged as a virus, even though it performs no legitimate function.

Many emails can be identified as viruses. If you are suspicious, call the person whose email it was, and tell them what it says. You will often find

To be more specific, we think that at this time, the communication of the tanker Urania to the local authorities is enough to ensure environmental safety. We are willing to share our communication with the nearby towns in this local website: https://www.comportadecreciente.com/comporta.html.                      As for the lagoons, the port authority will keep doing their inspections and reporting to the correct authorities. That is not under our scope.  If you could kindly refer to the annex you could find relevant information on what the port authority has to do.                      The final assessment of the damages and liability will be the jurisdiction of a tribunal, not the team from the UCRATIS.                      We look
Email 3:
Dear Mr. Lin,          The owner and charterer of the ship Urania have decided to take immediate action and ground the vessel in Escombreras Bay due to the alarm generated by the cargo spill of illegal poaching activities and, more recently, the news of the vessel leaving Malaga port for 8 hours without proper documentation. We would like to ask you to make an agreement to enable us to ground the vessel in Escombreras Bay, in compliance with our charter agreement, which, according to our lawyers, is a non-arbitral agreement. Please let us know how long it will take you to authorize our operation.          Best regards,          Jonathan Hagan

output_text:
From: anthony.operations@shippingco.com
To: lin.wei@ucratis.com
Subject: Urania Cargo Operations - Granules Delivery
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Hi Mr. Lin,

We will be sending 100MT of granules for your vessel Urania. Please advise if you will be needing seawater hose for the ballast operations?

Best regards,
Anthony

---

From: lin.wei@ucratis.com
To: anthony.operations@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Urania Cargo Operations - Granules Delivery
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:30
Body: Hello Anthony,

Thank you for your email.

The UCRATIS team has decided to take action in a different direction. The vessel Urania's communication with local authorities is sufficient for environmental safety compliance. Our communications with nearby towns can be found at: https://www.comportadecreciente.com/comporta.html

Regarding the lagoons, the port authority will continue their inspections and reporting. Please refer to the annex for details on port authority responsibilities.

Please note that any final assessment of damages and liability will fall under tribunal jurisdiction, not UCRATIS.

Best regards,
Mr. Lin

---

From: jonathan.hagan@chartering.com
To: lin.wei@ucratis.com
Subject: URGENT: Urania - Vessel Grounding Request
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:45
Body: Dear Mr. Lin,

The owner and charterer of the Urania have decided to take immediate action and ground the vessel in Escombreras Bay. This decision is due to the alarm generated by the cargo spill from illegal poaching activities and the vessel's unauthorized 8-hour departure from Malaga port.

We request your agreement to ground the vessel in Escombreras Bay, in compliance with our charter agreement (non-arbitral). Please advise on the timeline for authorization of this operation.

Best regards,
Jonathan Hagan

Email 2:
Thank you for your message.                     I calculated the possible shipping costs as below:                     Full Container Load - 400 EUR                    Groupage 24 MT - 210 EUR.

<Email 3>:
Thank you for your email.                     I calculated the margin based on full container load and margin for Kavala to Odessa is:                     0,4*120000 / 12 = 2000$. 
We should be able to offer 400 EUR as a surcharge for any container size, not only a 20ft one.                     Please, check once again and advise.                   Maria

Good afternoon Mr. Wright,                    We’re looking to move a 1,000TEU container from Hong Kong to Shanghai. We’d like to know your quickest loading time and if you offer any peak season surcharges.                    Hope to hear from you soon.                    Nate
Email 2:
I’m so glad that I was able to make this call at this time.                    I’ll need to make a few revisions to the shipment. The contract that we have listed is for an FCL shipment. But I think that you can only provide LCL service to Shanghai. And I’ve just received another email from Xingjiang about a small freight order. I’ll be sending them that confirmation number to reduce the suspense.                    I hope that we can talk soon to discuss how to ship the goods from Xingjiang to Shanghai.                    Hope to hear from you soon.                    Nate

## Solutions

The above emails make sense in the context of an actual email thread, but would be confusing if taken out of context. What we are doing is explaining why the first email was confusing. We can see the reasons for the confusion.

This means the first message is perfectly fine but as it is
Email 3:
<Email 4>:

What if we don’t have a conversation or an email thread, or just one word of an email is missing? For example, we have two messages (5 and 6) below

We might be able to figure out why message 5 is not a good email. But message 6 has to be a good email.

How about we use the above rationale to find out how many words are missing in the message? So a message should have a dot ‘.’ followed by a word followed by a dot ‘.’ and that word cannot be the same word in both messages. Then it will have to be something like this

dot ‘.’, “…“, dot ‘.’

Now the question is, how many dots are there? And how many “?” are there? 5 dots and 2 question marks, so we have

dot ‘.’, “…”, dot
Email 4:
What if we don’t have a conversation or an email thread, or just one word of an email is missing? For example, we have two messages (5 and 6) below

We might be able to figure out why message 5 is not a good email. But message 6 has to be a good email.

How about we use the above rationale to find out how many words are missing in the message? So a message should have a dot ‘.’ followed by a word followed by a dot ‘.’ and that word cannot be the same word in both messages. Then it will have to be something like this

dot ‘.’, “…“, dot ‘.’

Now the question is, how many dots are there? And how many “?” are there? 5 dots and 2 question marks, so we have

dot ‘.’, “…”, dot

<Email 4>:
 <Email 5>:

It was one dot instead of two. So we need to find out which word is missing. dot, how? I think the word ‘email’ is missing.

Check the spelling in the third message. If the spelling is right, then it is not the word. Now, is it okay for an English message to have two different spelling of a word?

So, the message 6 above is correct, because the word ‘word’ and ‘word’ can be different. And the word ‘how’ is the word that is missing. So we got it. 🙂

## Symbols and missing words

Symbols and other symbols in writing are a powerful and important tool. They make our writing look professional. It helps us make an impression on our audience. Symbols can be thought of as the ‘stamp of the author’.

It is even more important to use proper grammar,
Email 5:
It was one dot instead of two. So we need to find out which word is missing. dot, how? I think the word ‘email’ is missing.

Check the spelling in the third message. If the spelling is right, then it is not the word. Now, is it okay for an English message to have two different spelling of a word?

So, the message 6 above is correct, because the word ‘word’ and ‘word’ can be different. And the word ‘how’ is the word that is missing. So we got it. 🙂

## Symbols and missing words

Symbols and other symbols in writing are a powerful and important tool. They make our writing look professional. It helps us make an impression on our audience. Symbols can be thought of as the ‘stamp of the author’.

It is even more important to use proper grammar,

<Email 5>:
 , for example, when we are emailing or chatting with people.

Now, what about symbols like colon, comma, and semi-colon? How do we use them correctly? I think it is good to learn about proper punctuation for email or writing because it helps to communicate your ideas in a clear and effective manner. So, let’s start with colon ‘:’!

The colon is a punctuation mark that is used to separate a main idea from a supporting one in writing. If we look at the sentence below,

The food was very tasty: I ate two bowls.

We can see that there is a main idea and a supporting one. In this case, the main idea is the food was tasty. And the supporting one is that the person ate two bowls of food.

Hi John,                    Sorry, we have received your email and are still checking our inventory. Please give us 48 hours to check our stock, and we will revert back with our updated ETA.                    Regards,                    Linda
Email 2:
Dear Linda,                    My product's quantity is now down to zero. We hope to replenish our stock shortly. We will let you know the new ETA.                    Kind Regards,                    John

  1. This email was sent in reply to the previous email.
  2. Email 2 was sent to Linda.

Is there an automated reply sent when an email is not received by Linda or John (who is the intended recipient)? How will you track the case manually?

To answer this question, let’s imagine that both emails are sent at the same time.

In this example, we send two emails to Linda from John at the same time. They reach Linda at approximately the same time.

As we know, we often use a three-day buffer in our automated emails. This gives us time to confirm that an email is received by the intended recipient before sending an automated reply.

An automated

output_text:
From: jackie.trader@trading.com
To: chichi.analyst@trading.com
Subject: Crude Oil Breakout Analysis
Timestamp: 2013-10-15 09:23
Body: Good morning Chichi,

It looks like the NBP (Net Breakout Position) is breaking out to the upside. Is this a genuine bullish move?

If so, we must consider increasing our exposure to crude options from the low 40s to the 70s.

Regards,
Jackie

---

From: chichi.analyst@trading.com
To: jackie.trader@trading.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Breakout Analysis
Timestamp: 2013-10-15 10:45
Body: Hi Jackie,

I would love to take credit for the move in crude. However, this is primarily event-driven.

After the Q4 2013 outlook call, crude oil finished strong but the 42.5 handle didn't sustain. Looking at the bigger picture, crude is confirming our trading zone of 40-46.

There are additional market factors at play that I'll elaborate on in my next analysis.

Stay tuned!

Chichi

---

From: jackie.trader@trading.com
To: chichi.analyst@trading.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Breakout Analysis
Timestamp: 2013-10-15 11:30
Body: Good morning Chichi,

With the 50 EMA just about to hit the 42.5 handle, would this be a good time to place the cut-loss order?

Regards,
Jackie

---

From: chichi.analyst@trading.com
To: jackie.trader@trading.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Breakout Analysis
Timestamp: 2013-10-15 12:15
Body: Jackie,

Here's the breakout scenario:

- At 38.5 handle, crude was in a trading zone
- At 40, it closed above 38.5 handle (outside trading range)
- We came in at 40.2 on the 7/23 call, triggering the highest swing up since 7/2 (42.5)
- At 42.5, we enter an overbought zone (up-trending market)

A stop is not necessary because our exit (42.5) is extremely protective.

Best,
Chichi

To add a picture of yourself, send me a screenshot of you on a boat, or a picture of you with a cup of coffee in hand.                    Add your name to the subject line and your name to the greeting at the beginning of the email.                    I can help you build the email if you do not know how. Agora, a quantidade de produto das florestas do Brasil começou a “explosão”.                          Mas agora, temos dificuldades de transporte.               Rio de Janeiro é quase a metade da distância entre Salvador e Maputo.           E o canal do Panamá no momento está parado com a chuva. Email 3:

Não temos problemas transportando grãos desde que as canais no Oceano Atlântico estão abertos.          Nós entramos para fazer um pequeno caminho em Zimbabve e temos uma abertura única em Ruanda. Eu queria fazer o caminho todo para a S.AFRICA mas tenho a desconfiança do canal do Panamá. A situação parece muito ruim no canal em 2019/2020.          Nós pudemos cruzar o Atlântico com segurança. I also bought 4×4 vehicles, Mercedes Benz and Toyota Landcruiser for private import.          I now import grains from the USA, Canada, Australia, South Africa and West Africa.          Today we bring over a million MTs of fertilizers.          I just delivered 2,000MT of potassium chloride fertilizer.          I just delivered 50,000MT of Nitrogen fertilizer.                    NUFertilizer is a soft fertilizer.                    We have ready stocks. 500,000MT in storage.                      Usually, we ship weekly. But this week we are running low on stocks.

Body: Olá Mr. Neko,

I've been exporting timber to Southern Africa for 6 years now. The trade has been spectacular. While Canadians and Australians previously dominated the market, Brazilian forest products are now experiencing significant growth.

From: neko@maputo-shipping.co.mz
To: cachorro@brazil-exports.com

Best regards,
Neko

Neko

Dear Mr. Wu,                    Could you please send us your earliest laycan dates for 2,500MT of iron ore from Vigo to Kaohsiung?                    Sincerely,                    Darren
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Wu,                    Please let me know your current laycan dates for 2,500MT of iron ore from Vigo to Kaohsiung, and also if you will be able to adjust this quantity up to 5,000MT per shipment.                    Regards,                    Darren

<Email 3>:
Dear Mr. Wu,                    I am writing to inform you that we are no longer interested in your offer. We are cancelling this inquiry.                    Best regards,                    Darren

Mr. Wu received three emails from Ms. Watson, each of which requested different information.

1. The first email asked for a quote for the quantity 2,500MT. The email asked for the earliest laycan date.
2. The second email requested a quote for the quantity 2,500MT, but with the requirement that the quote be adjusted up to 5,000MT
Email 3:
Dear Mr. Wu,                    I am writing to inform you that we are no longer interested in your offer. We are cancelling this inquiry.                    Best regards,                    Darren

Mr. Wu received three emails from Ms. Watson, each of which requested different information.

1. The first email asked for a quote for the quantity 2,500MT. The email asked for the earliest laycan date.
2. The second email requested a quote for the quantity 2,500MT, but with the requirement that the quote be adjusted up to 5,000MT

<Email 3>:
 Cancelled, _time after 1st email_

3. The third email, which came in response to Email 2, cancelled the inquiry. This email was sent 4 minutes after Email 2 was sent.
Email 3 is an example of **what is commonly known as non-standard data elements**. It is a specific requirement for this system. This kind of requirement is normally given when developing a system.

output_text:
From: sarah.thompson@globalfreight.com
To: j.davis@davislogistics.com
Subject: Thank You for Your Service & Important Update
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Mr. Davis,

May we take this opportunity to say thank you for the excellent job you are doing with our shipping operations. Over the past year, we have seen significant improvements to your processes, efficiency, and accuracy, and for this we are very thankful.

As you know, at Global Freight, it is our priority to provide safe, efficient and reliable transportation, and we know you hold the same values.

For this reason, we wanted to be transparent and let you know that we have started working with another carrier for some of our routes. While they are offering lower rates, we value the reliability and trust we've built with your company. If you find that your costs are affecting your competitiveness, we would be happy to discuss this further.

We remain committed to maintaining our business relationship and look forward to continuing our partnership.

Best regards,
Sarah Thompson
Global Freight Solutions

---

From: j.davis@davislogistics.com
To: sarah.thompson@globalfreight.com
Subject: Re: Thank You for Your Service & Important Update
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Dear Ms. Thompson,

Thank you for your candid communication and the kind words about our service quality. We greatly value our partnership with Global Freight Solutions and appreciate your transparency regarding the new carrier relationship.

I would welcome the opportunity to review our current rates and discuss how we can continue to provide you with the best value while maintaining our high service standards.

Could we schedule a meeting next week to discuss this further?

Best regards,
James Davis
Davis Logistics

Louis

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Ms. Young,                    We would like to charter a vessel from the ports of Singapore and Saldanha Bay (Puntas de Marennes) and agree to a rate of $0,5 per net register ton.                      Would you be able to charter this vessel with clearance of 10.5m, and are you able to provide a schedule of your operations for 2014?                    Sincerely,                    Ken
Email 2:
Hi,                        Thanks for your message. Sorry it took me a while to reply but I was out of office for a couple of days.                      The full schedule of our current charter rates is posted on our website.                              This is the link:     http://www.safmarine.com/trade/markets/Schedules/Schedule%20of%20Ships%20Rates%202014.pdf                      We currently have no availability of vessels available to charter from Singapore in 2014 and do not know of any scheduled repairs for our vessels in 2014.                      Kind regards,                      Amy                     MRJC: 297892

Comments
Email 1 is more appropriate than Email 2. Why? In the Email 1, a disclaimer is found at the end. Email 2 includes more information than Email 1.

• The sender should always check for disclaimers at the end of
Email 3:
Dear Mr. Peters,
I'm looking for an email to use as a follow-up email to an

• What if the subject of the email is about or from an unknown person?

• If you email somebody, be aware that a disclosure statement must be made if

When replying, use a generic subject:

• For example: "Contractual problems".

Note that some companies may not appreciate you contacting their employees at home by email. Some employees may also respond at their office's email address.

• What if the email is very urgent? If the email is urgent, you can

Return to: Previous Paragraph | Next Paragraph
Email 4:
If you're emailing someone, be aware that the recipient can see the original message if you include headers in the e-mail. To prevent people from seeing the message headers, add this line to the header of your email:
Email 5:
Return to: Previous Paragraph | Next Paragraph
Email 5:
Always specify if an email is a formal request. For example:

" I'm attaching a draft copy of a letter to discuss the options we have to resolve the problem at the scheduled meeting on Wednesday."

• Can I send emails with attachments if the recipient is from another company?
There's no reason why a person from one company cannot send an email with an attachment to another company. It is a good idea to send attachments in a compressed format such as zip or rar.

Return to: Previous Paragraph | Next Paragraph

input_text:
Email 1:
Best Mr. Hardy,                    I’m arranging 3,200MT of green coffee from Sousse to Glasgow. Could you advise if you can fit this in early October, and what's your standard demurrage clause?                    Best regards,                    Ana
Email 2:
Best Ana,                      I can get it to the port at the end of September, and 28 days’ demurrage will be charged, as the other suppliers require that, as they like their clearance early.                      Best regards,                      Rob
Email 3:
Best Ana,                   Thanks for your email, looks like a good package for the market. Thanks for your offer too, but the container isn't arriving until early October, and that is too late for the market to absorb.                      Best regards,                      Rob
<Email 4>:
Best Mr. Hardy,                  A huge thanks for your help! The coffee is booked.                        Best regards,                        Ana

## Message Sequencing

In the above example, Ana arranged coffee through three different emails, and Mr. Hardy gave feedback on one occasion. To get a clear picture of the discussion, it's necessary to read the messages in a consistent order.

Using the following information, you can sequence each email, and figure out the order of the conversation.

• Email 2: Received on September 15
• Email 3: Received on September 16
•
Email 4:
Best Mr. Hardy,                  A huge thanks for your help! The coffee is booked.                        Best regards,                        Ana

## Message Sequencing

In the above example, Ana arranged coffee through three different emails, and Mr. Hardy gave feedback on one occasion. To get a clear picture of the discussion, it's necessary to read the messages in a consistent order.

Using the following information, you can sequence each email, and figure out the order of the conversation.

• Email 2: Received on September 15
• Email 3: Received on September 16
•

<Email 4>:
 Received on September 16
• Email 1: Received on September 15
• Email 2: Sent on September 15
• Email 3: Sent on September 16
•

## Backscatter

The email sequences above were generated from pre-written message templates. Backscatter is a technique in which an auto-generated response is sent to the sender, without human intervention. This sort of reply looks as though the recipient is interacting with the sender.

To prevent backscatter, you can check each individual email for backscatter, or implement tools that stop messages from being sent automatically to a human.

In the email examples above, an auto-receipt would be sent to Ana. The auto-reply would say something like:

Thank you for your email. It has been forwarded to our assigned coffee broker, Mr. Hardy. Mr. Hardy will contact you soon to arrange the details of this order.
Email 5:
Best Ana,                  Thanks for your email, looks like a good package for the market. Thanks for your offer too, but the container isn't arriving until early October, and that is too late for the market to absorb.                      Best regards,                      Rob

Thank you for your cooperation,
Alan Jones

Subject: Re: Aviation Fuel Shipment Inquiry - Houston to Amsterdam
Timestamp: 2023-09-16 14:20
Body: Dear Mr. Bravo,

The documents look fine to me, but there are two things you have to do:

1. Find another mode of transport for the remaining 1,200 MT of aviation fuel, which the customer won't take back. You can make a lot of money with this volume, as this aviation fuel is due to be consumed on the day you will receive it in Amsterdam. The customer does not want to transport the 1,200 MT to Belgium, so you should sell this additional aviation fuel on a spot basis and ensure proper credit risk management.

2. Sell your FOB Hamburg cargo to the customer for a lump sum to secure full value.

Please use the additional document we discussed to cover all risks.

Regards,
Mrs. Smythe

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Mr. Mercer,                    We’re looking at shipping 3,000MT of nonferrous metals from Hakata to New York. Do you have any available service for early August, and what’s your standard demurrage clause?                    Regards,                    Stephane
Email 2:
Mr. Mercer, I spoke to the Customs broker inquiring about the subject trade. He has confirmed that you’re the best carrier for the specific service we’re looking for. Can you confirm the ability to handle this cargo in August, and what’s your standard demurrage clause for this period?                      Please feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions.                      Best regards,                      Stephane

Both emails were correct and professional in content and tone. The second, from an existing customer, was respectful, courteous, and business-like. It included more of the details needed to address the need. It built on the relationship and expanded on the positive interactions. You used a gentle invitation to express interest and explore further: “If you have any questions.”
The first, from a prospective customer, included the key details required. It was short and to the point, and also used a
Email 3:
Thank you for your proposal. I will get back to you shortly regarding the availability and question on demurrage.                      Regards,                      Stephane

. It was only three sentences long. You could send the response right away, and that’s important. Did you follow up?
Mr. Mercer, please find my response regarding the availability of your service to Hakata in early August.                      As far as demurrage, our preference is 4.00 a day + $1.50 per hour. Also, would you be able to ship to the Pier 84 terminal in New York City?                      Thank you for your prompt response.                      Regards,                      Stephane
This is a succinct and polite message. “Thank you” can be omitted, but I included it as a sign of respect. I included the terms for demurrage and the preferred location. When replying to a
Email 4:
Hi Stephane,
Re: your request for service to Hakata in early August.
Regarding demurrage, you may ship up to 4.00 a day plus $1.50 per hour. This demurrage will be invoiced, not collected. The Carrier may ship to Pier 84.
Thank you,
David

. We may reply directly to the client. We should address the specific request if appropriate, but we need to reply before the quoted deadline, and that’s important. Did you reply within the quoted period?
Just an update regarding my request for service to Hakata in early August. It’s a job ready to ship from August 1 to August 14. What would be the earliest available departure for this trade?
Did you follow up?
Mr. Mercer, I have a short update regarding my original request. Our client is willing to change the origin to California instead
Email 5:
Hi David,                          I just want to thank you for the great service you provided for our import. It was a great experience, and we will surely come back.                          Thank you for the good communication and cooperation with our customs broker.                          Best regards,                          Stephane

Email 1:
Dear Mr Au,                    I need a vessel for 20,000MT of BP500 jet fuel from Korea to Hong Kong. Could you confirm if a mid-June laycan works for you, and are port dues included in your quote?                    Many thanks,                    Precious
Email 2:
Dear Mr Ng,                    Thank you for your prompt reply, and I confirm that a mid-June laycan works for me. Please confirm your availability to help me find a suitable vessel. I am most impressed with your professional handling of the request. Thank you again for your efforts.                     Regards,                    Precious
Email 3:
Dear Ms Khor,                    Thank you for your reply. I was on leave, hence the delayed response. I believe that there is ample shipping capacity, however, the slots are very competitive. We will begin discussions on rate once a vessel is identified.                         Regards,                     Precious


An Example of Getting Quotes:
In one example, we got quotes for 40,000MT from Incheon to Ningbo, 15,000MT from Singapore to China and 20,000MT from Shanghai to China, among other lessor profitable cargoes from South Korea. We tried our best to minimise the freight cost, because we are a young business. As the shipping industry is dominated by cartel-like players, the cost of shipping is difficult to control.

After securing the best quotes and making a calculation, the total cost of shipping was less than S$20,000. In terms of price
Email 4:
Dear Mr Lau,                    Thank you for all your efforts to secure the shipping quotation. We managed to secure two vessels and are currently in negotiation with the carriers to secure rates for both slots. We will send you an update as soon as we know more.                     Regards,                    Precious
Email 5:
Dear Ms Khor,                    We secured both slots, and the final cost of shipping will be less than S$20,000.                    Many thanks,                    Precious


It is important to think about this from the carrier’s perspective, as every shipper has the same cargo. I constantly kept an eye on rates for the same dates as the shippers were looking at, so I could check whether the shippers were taking advantage of rates. The rates of the carriers would change at different times based on many factors, including demand and supply. In fact, there is also a cap on rates by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) due to the deep-sea shipping market becoming an oligopoly, with only a few shipping companies dominating the global shipping market, as is the case with many industries today. As mentioned, it is difficult to find lower rates if they are limited by the IMO,

Dear Gomes,                    We just saw the order for FREYSSINET and I wonder if you are planning any further shipments soon. We are available to provide you with a supply chain which works and will enable you to ship on a strict ETA. Our project teams have vast experience working with organizations of your size and we are able to guarantee you will get your goods delivered when you need them.                    Sincerely,                    James
Email 2:
James,

I just saw the email you sent out about our inventory. I know that this is a response that most people can find off the web but I really appreciate that you took the time to read our order and get back to me. I would like to keep a few thoughts that you brought up in mind during your email to make a decision about our contract.

I am sorry that I had such a hard time when I was trying to place the order. I didn't have a consultant. I did research the prices of FREYSSINET and thought I would do a better job than a consultant. Your note made me think of another idea. Maybe there are even more sources than I could find on my own. There is no doubt that we could get a better price from an agent than a consultant or if you were to provide one, we can save money.

I'm impressed with your analysis
Email 3:
James,
Thanks for responding to my email. I got a lot of information from your email. I'm sure you don't write these responses every day but it really helps a customer.

I'm especially happy about your last thought about the use of agent or consultant. I did a little research and I learned that you use consultants in about 10% of your orders. This was encouraging to me because we would not be the first. You may want to think about that before you send out the next email. I think we would save enough on fees with a consultant and agent that it would make us come out a lot ahead. Let me know if you'd like to discuss it further.

Sincerely,
[YourName]

Hello Ms. Jensen,                    I would like to change the loading date of my cargo from Johor to Kaohsiung from 16th August to the 20th August. Are you open for the change, or can you not accept?                    Kindly,                    Emmet
Email 2:
Hi Emmet,                         The suggested date is fine for us, and we accept your request.                    Kind regards,                    RIA

Emmet
Email 3:
Hello Ciaran,                        I would like to send another re-booking request, please. On the current booking from Port Harcourt to Benin I was given a trade name as the loading mark for container H44. I have received the correct container, however this trade name was not on the bill of lading. I have taken a screenshot of the container with my mobile phone, which I have attached to this email. I have asked the forwarding agent at the port to contact you, to confirm the correct trade name should be on the bill of lading. I request that the bill of lading be amended, to show the correct trade name, and this email be sent to me with the email from you, stating that the bill of lading has been changed. Please amend the booking on the system, and the email be sent to me. I will forward the B/L change to

Hello Ciaran,
                        On behalf of our client, we regret to advise that there are some incorrect declarations on the booking from Port Harcourt to Benin, and thus the entry of the container in this booking is prohibited. The corrected declaration must be sent to us for approval, before the booking can be re-registered. Please advise.
                        Kindly,
Email 5:
Hello Emmet,
                        Unfortunately, we can not accommodate the amendments requested for the booking from Port Harcourt to Benin, because this booking is being intercepted on behalf of our client. As we cannot approve these changes, the booking must be dropped. 
                        Kindly,

Ciaran

Kindly,
Ciaran

##  How to send email with Klaviyo:

### Insert the email code

1. Log in to Klaviyo.
2. Click **Emails**.
3. Select **Settings** and click **Email Codes**.
4. Click **Insert**.

### Test the email

1. Open an email template in the **Design** section.
2. Click **Email Code** to see the list of email codes.
3. Double-click the code and the code becomes a placeholder.

### Set up
Email 4:
We are looking to sell 100,000 MT of gasoline for export. Can you give me your latest prices and laycan dates for July-September?

4. In the **Message** section, fill in the details to set up the message.
5. In the **Build** section, check the email as you want.
6. Click **Save** to save.

### Send the email

1. Click **Draft** or **Active**.
2. In the **Subject** section, enter a subject.
3. Click **Send** to send the email.

### Review

1. The sent message will appear in the **Sent** tab.
2. To view the message history, click the dropdown next to the **Send** button.

### Troubleshooting

#### The email doesn’t work

When the email does not work, the following solutions will help you:

1. Check
Email 5:
I sent an email for MERCOSUR and I am trying to send an email for KUROSHIO. I didn’t receive an answer for the 1st email. Please help me. I will pay the required fees.

2. Wait

Dearest O’Donnell,                    Could your vessel load 7,500MT of pyridine from Minoan in Zhoushan in early June? Would you confirm if your vessel can handle a mid-July laycan, and at what cost?                    Best regards,                    Patrick
Email 2:
Thanks for your early inquiry. Our client asks for a May 10, 2022 arrival in Tianjin, in 30 days' time. At the moment, it seems doable, as we have availability for 7,500MT pyridine. This could be via our 29,000 DWT Suezmax ship (slated for lifting) and chartering a 50,000 DWT VLCC, or by chartering a 50,000 DWT Suezmax (travelling round via the Suez Canal) or a 60,000 DWT VLCC. This would give you 6-7 weeks' notice for loading in Zhoushan. The total cost would be in the ballpark of US$8.5 million (about $0.10/bbl and $0.08/bbl for loading and charters). You would incur
output_text:
From: patrick.mckenzie@minoan-shipping.com
To: odonnell.james@oceantransport.com
Subject: Pyridine Shipment Inquiry - Zhoushan to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2022-04-10 09:15
Body: Dearest O'Donnell,

Could your vessel load 7,500MT of pyridine from Minoan in Zhoushan in early June? Would you confirm if your vessel can handle a mid-July laycan, and at what cost?

Best regards,
Patrick

---

From: odonnell.james@oceantransport.com
To: patrick.mckenzie@minoan-shipping.com
Subject: Re: Pyridine Shipment Inquiry - Zhoushan to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2022-04-10 14:30
Body: Dear Patrick,

Thanks for your early inquiry. Our client requires arrival in Tianjin by May 10, 2022, which is approximately 30 days from now. We can accommodate the 7,500MT pyridine shipment through either:

1. Our 29,000 DWT Suezmax vessel with additional 50,000 DWT VLCC charter
2. A chartered 50,000 DWT Suezmax via Suez Canal
3. A chartered 60,000 DWT VLCC

This arrangement would provide 6-7 weeks' notice for loading in Zhoushan. Total estimated cost would be US$8.5 million (including loading and charter rates at $0.10/bbl and $0.08/bbl respectively).

Best regards,
James O'Donnell

We are looking to hire a project manager for a 400km long network of seawall repairs on the long island coast of Indonesia. We need you to prepare a proposal with all the necessary technical specifications. It is of course a highly secretive and secure project that requires the highest possible integrity, so we need you to make sure that no one in your organisation knows about this, or we will not accept the proposal. However, as you are aware, both India and Indonesia are equally strategic countries, and as the
Email 2:

We look forward to working with you on this project!                    Kinan & Keshab, One Universe Global Plc.

From: projects@indonesian-seawalls.com
To: ['kinan@oneuniverse.com', 'keshab@oneuniverse.com']
Subject: Confidential: Indonesia Seawall Project - Project Manager Position
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 18:30
Body: Good evening Messrs. Kinan & Keshab,

You have my apologies for having to contact you on such an important matter, but my boss was called away for a sudden family emergency, and I had to fill in for him.

We are looking to hire a project manager for a 400km long network of seawall repairs on the long island coast of Indonesia. We need you to prepare a proposal with all the necessary technical specifications. It is of course a highly secretive and secure project that requires the highest possible integrity, so we need you to make sure that no one in your organisation knows about this, or we will not accept the proposal.

This project will be conducted by a consortium of foreign experts and we are asking you to contribute with your expertise on seawalls.

Best regards

---

Subject: Re: Confidential: Indonesia Seawall Project - Project Manager Position

We look forward to working with you on this project!

Best regards,
Kinan & Keshab
One Universe Global Plc.

From: matthieu.lambert@shipping.com

Timestamp: 2016-01-26 10:15
Body: Bonjour,

1. Commercial Transshipment Requirements:
- SGM cargo delivery must align with terminal arrival dates
- Booking changes must be requested before commercial transshipment starts
- Door-to-door service arrangements must be confirmed in advance

- Jinqiao Mahul Terminal does not accept containers from Zone 2
- First container release in 45 days after loading completion
- Remaining containers release in 50 days
- Containers must be released from original storage area

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello David,                    What’s the freight quote to Singapore for 50,000MT of granulated slag (2,000MT in single loads) from Hamburg next month? Also, what’s your estimated transit time to Singapore?                    Best,                    Yinan
Email 2:
1. The freight quote is: $1,396,652 2. The estimated transit time is: 35 days (not counting loading / unloading time)

<<Brutal Definition of CVR>>:
A CVR refers to “Customer Value Retention Rate”. In other words, it is the percentage of customers that come back to you for a repeat order.

For example, if you sold 200 widgets to company A, 50% of those widgets were purchased again the next time A purchased from you.

In this example, your CVR is 50%.

You can also use this to measure the life-time value of your customers. If you have 200 customers and your CVR is 30%, you can assume that on average 60 of your customers are going to keep buying from you until they die.

Note: These measurements can be used to accurately predict how well
Email 3:
I have two customers who have kept buying from me repeatedly, one for 1,000 orders and the other for 2,000 orders. Are they using my online tool, or are they just purchasing over the phone, or both?

There’s no clear answer to this, but here are a few pointers to help you make sense of this.

Remember that the CVR (Customer Value Retention Rate) is the percentage of customers that come back to you for a repeat order. You can calculate this by looking at the percentage of orders that came back to you (or came back to you but didn’t purchase again)

So, if you sold 200 widgets to company A, 50% of those widgets were purchased again the next time A purchased from you. In this example, your CVR is 50%. Note: these measurements can be used to accurately predict how well your company’s
Email 4:
I have one customer who purchased from me 2,000 times over a period of 20 years. Is he using my online tool? What about all the others?

Well, you can’t just blindly assume that everyone who has purchased from you is using the same tools. So, you need to make a few assumptions:

1. If your customer made 2,000 purchases over a period of 20 years, then you can assume that he used your tools for at least 20 years (that is, 20 years ago).
Email 5:
I am thinking about using your plugin for e-commerce. Do you have a plan to monetize it? Or do you plan to offer it for free?

Yes, I have a plan to monetize the plugin. I plan to do this by offering the plugin as a monthly subscription. The subscription will be priced at $100 per month. In other words, you will need to pay$100 per month to use the plugin.

This is one of the ways that I plan to monetize the plugin. The other way is by selling the plugin as a paid one-time purchase. I will be discussing this more in the next few days.

Hi,

I'm looking for a professional developer to perform 2 simple tasks for me. The first one is to make a copy of our website content from a subdomain to another. The second one is to make a backup of a WordPress database and its files to a local disk.

I can provide a brief description of each task.

## Sending emails

### Formal emails

Emails that follow a strict, impersonal format. They do not include your name or job title and are directed to an impersonal address, such as info@ or sales@. These emails are usually written for marketing purposes, or for those who have not been introduced. A formal email should not be written with a sense of familiarity; it should show formality and respect.

In a formal email, you should include your name, organization, email address, and phone number. Additionally, it is helpful

input_text:
Email 1:
Good Morning Captain Schuppe,                    We’re planning to ship 6,000MT of raw material from Rotterdam to Algeciras, could you please advise of any available laycan slots, as well as any additional freight charges.                    Regards,                    Ryan
Email 2:
Good Morning Captain Schuppe,                    We’ve been receiving bids from the following vessels: Exxpresser, Futura, Goya, Super Valiant, Tyra and Valspar.                    Could you please confirm that your vessel is able to load 6,000MT at Rotterdam?                    Regards,                    Ryan

Email 1:
Good Afternoon Captain Schuppe,                    Our vessel the Exxpresser, will be arriving to Rotterdam in 8 days. She is arriving on 1:30pm Rotterdam time on July 1st. We are looking at offloading her to a spot in Algeciras. Please advise the following:                      How will we communicate with your ship once we are ready to load the cargo?                         How do you pay your pilot?                         What will be the weekly rate to pilot your ship?                         Do you have a safety system on board?
Email 3:
Your offer to pilot our vessel, as well as the safety systems, check list and your safety instructions were all well received. I have passed these on to our client. However, there is an issue we had not discussed yet, and we would like to get this sorted out before I can proceed with the rest of your request.                    It appears that our regular pilot cannot make it to the port, and we were asking if you would be available to pilot our vessel on July 1st.                    With respect,                    Ryan

<Email 4>:
Hello Captain Schuppe,                    On June 30th, the port pilot for our vessel was unable to go to Rotterdam. We have no idea how long this issue will last, however, we are in the midst of our planning phase. We will know more once we have information from the cargo owners and our client. Please do not delay
output_text:

To: capt.schuppe@maritime.com
Subject: Cargo Inquiry Rotterdam-Algeciras 6,000MT
Timestamp: 2023-06-25 09:30
Body: Good Morning Captain Schuppe,

Ryan

input_text:
Email 1:
Max,                    We’ve got 13,500MT of heavy gasoline in Cartagena that we’d like to ship out asap. Could you provide a preliminary quote and confirm if you handle port dues under FOB terms?                    Best regards,                    Dan
Email 2:
Hi,                   With regard to your message above, I’m happy to start a conversation about your logistics needs. It seems there are some potential risks, including weather impact and Suez Canal bottlenecks that will affect transportation. As such, the earliest available vessel for loading the cargo is not for another 14 days. However, you can still ship this cargo by the fastest available vessel for an additional premium of 7% if you are prepared to pay for the cost difference and the fees associated with carrying the risk of uncertainty. The sea freight cost is typically cheaper because the additional cost will only be incurred in the unlikely event of an inevitable delay or cancelation. I am attaching some indicative transport cost estimates for your review. These calculations are based on the available information, including port dues, and thus these figures may be subject to change depending on the final contract details.                    Kind regards,                    Simon
Email 3:
Dear Max,                   Thank you for your prompt response, I will confirm the exact volumes by the end of today, our usual weekly schedule is the 27th January.                     In the meantime, this cargo is classified as an LPG product and is subject to a 2% surcharge due to the very high shipping cost.                     If you’re ready, I will send the final quote to you today.                     Thanks,                     Simon

Email 1: Hi Mr. Bernard, I am traveling to Baku, and I want you to ship 2,800MT of gasoline from there to Al Sharqia. I am sure there will be some delay at the port, but I am not sure whether that is part of the delivery time or not. Could you please explain the procedures for your company to take such situations into account? Thank you, Linda Email 2: I am sorry, but you must not send your documents with the tank measure numbers on it. We are going to have an examination on the delivered gasoline, and we need to know what quantity we are getting to do that. I will appreciate it if you could send the updated copies of your invoice without the tank measure numbers. Thank you, Anna

KALYAN (M. D.):

Delivered 08.02.2018 | Marka: 100-05-160-8000.6; Kafe: ADYCEMY.100-05-160-8000.6 | Pack (km): 1137; MT:

— _________________________________ ________________

_____________________________ ________________

_______________________________________

_____________________________ Email 3: Dear Mr. Bernard, I need you to ship 1,200 MT of gasoline to Tripoli from your company. We have a contract with another company that is providing us with 2,400 MT for our needs, but we did not receive the full amount due to the delay in transportation, and we only have the means to buy what we have in our budget. We will have to stop the buying and do something about the current shortage of fuel, and so, I have made an immediate order of 1,200 MT that I would like you to deliver. I hope you will be able to help us and deliver the fuel immediately. Thank you. Anna

KALYAN (M. D.):

Delivered 07.02.2018 | Marka: Email 4: Dear Mr. Bernard,

I know you are trying to do your best, but I would like to talk to you about the time that is needed for the shipping and delivering of the fuel. My company needs to continue the imports of fuel because of the winter weather and also because of the heat wave. Unfortunately, the delay in the delivery of the fuel is really harming our business. Could you please think of something that you can do to avoid the delays? I think you understand what I am trying to say because your company is also in the same line of business that we are in. Thank you for listening, Anna

KALYAN (M. D.):

Delivered 05.02.2018 | Marka: 100-05-160-8000.

From: anna.peters@fuelsupply.com
To: bernard.smith@globalshipping.com
Subject: Urgent: Additional 1,200MT Gasoline Order to Tripoli
Timestamp: 2018-02-07 10:45
Body: Dear Mr. Bernard,

I need you to ship 1,200 MT of gasoline to Tripoli from your company. We have a contract with another company that is providing us with 2,400 MT for our needs, but we did not receive the full amount due to the delay in transportation, and we only have the means to buy what we have in our budget. We will have to stop the buying and do something about the current shortage of fuel, and so, I have made an immediate order of 1,200 MT that I would like you to deliver.

I hope you will be able to help us and deliver the fuel immediately.

Anna

My company needs to continue the imports of fuel because of the winter weather and also because of the heat wave. Unfortunately, the delay in the delivery of the fuel is really harming our business. Could you please think of something that you can do to avoid the delays? I think you understand what I am trying to say because your company is also in the same line of business that we are in.

Thank you for listening,
Anna

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi,                    We have 8,000MT of propane available to ship from Newcastle to Hull, UK. Could you check if there are any laycan slots available and a bunker surcharge anticipated?                    Best,                    Ayman
Email 2:
Hi,                    Thank you for your inquiry. I have sent an email to an agent working on your booking. Best Regards, James
    
    <Email 3>:                    
    Hi,                    Thank you for your booking. Please find the rates attached. Kind Regards, James


The above exchange takes place between the buyer and seller via email. Assuming that all parties understand each other and agree on the exchange terms, this is how a contract is concluded. A lot of businesses carry out this process via emails as it is considered the most efficient way to carry out business.

The business world is all about "time is money". Therefore, the quicker you resolve a problem, the more value you add to the transaction. However, 70% of emails are received and read without being opened and only 35% are responded to. With this in mind, the emails need to be concise, accurate and to
Email 3:
the point.

| |

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Mr. Sangwoo,                    We’re looking to discharge an LTL container at Rotterdam on the 27th, and transit it to London with a FTL 20-footer. Could you quote a warehouse at London to receive the container on the 30th?                    Regards,                    Mikhail
Email 2:
Good morning,                   I can manage this request in Asia but I am worried about how they will handle the shipment if we can only do it at the last minute, especially if there is a difference in our order timeline.            Regards,            Miki
Email 3:
Hi.                        I tried to do this, but now my co-workers are approaching me saying it’s too expensive. I am feeling very disappointed.            Regards,            Julia

Hello Julia,                    I’ve sent an email, which I sent to Julia’s other email address (different from Mikhail’s) that should work.
                        Since they didn’t respond to you, they probably think it’s not worth it for them to respond to a younger employee. I am extremely disappointed in them as well.              In order to be able to respond to the urgency of the situation, you should be a manager. Unfortunately, that’s how the company is built.                     However, you might be able to convince them that it’s actually a better solution to work with someone who is younger and more flexible than a manager. This is a pretty great opportunity for you and I am sad that you don’t have the power
Email 4:
Good morning,
We’re looking to discharge an LTL container at Rotterdam on the 27th, and transit it to London with a FTL 20-footer. Could you quote a warehouse at London to receive the container on the 30th? Regards, 
Mikhail

Note: This is the actual response that I have received from Julia's co-worker. He replied with no reference to Mikhail's response.

Hello Mikhail,
We can do that if you make a booking for it at once. Please make an order and I will let you know the price and date.

Miki

In my opinion, Julia’s co-worker made the right choice in choosing this strategy, since he did not want to respond to Mikhail’s email. As you can see, in the second email, Miki offers to take Mikhail’s project, since it is not worth a manager to deal with that. In order
Email 5:
However, Mikhail wasn’t satisfied with Miki’s reply because he wanted the project to be carried out at a lower price. Julia’s co-worker chose to use this strategy because Mikhail was not a manager. I strongly believe that the company’s higher management should not respond to younger employees, but to those who are in a position to make decisions.

- The exact arrival time for the package is not guaranteed, sometimes the delay can take up to 24 hours, also,

Would you please confirm delivery by any of these dates?                    Many thanks,                    Chen
Email 2:
Dear Chen,                 I apologize for the delay in my response. However, I need some more information to confirm our schedule. Specifically, I need to know which product to ship to Osaka on which day, i.e. Tuesday, May 29th or Wednesday, May 30th. Since we are unable to offer a rate for an incomplete request, I have not replied earlier. We need a day-by-day schedule of the products being shipped to Osaka. Once we have this information, we will be able to provide you with an accurate rate and transit time. For instance, if the products are the same every day, then you can provide us with the total amount of products and the total transit time is two days.                    Thank you for your cooperation.                    Regards,                    Jonas

Hi Jonas,                     First, I apologize for the confusion, the shipper will contact you to provide the actual details of the cargo.                    I will attach our cargo information, and please confirm the arrival date of each cargo, or we'll be calling on Daesan with 3 to 5 trailers of the same cargo.                    Thanks,                     Chen

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Luis,                    It has been brought to my attention that you will be handling the documentation for our client at Funchal next month. However, we cannot guarantee 50% of the documentation requirements, such as notices of loads and demurrage. We will not hold ourselves accountable for any further costs incurred.                    If you would like to discuss this further, please contact me.                    Best wishes,                    Margarita Madison
Email 2:
Dear Margarita,                 I am sorry to hear that the documentation will not be ready. This could lead to major headaches on the day of sailing. It would also put extra pressure on our client, and I cannot have that.                 I believe that you must issue all of the documentation to be presented. I have explained to you that this is the only way that I can ensure the safety of my client's interests.                 I need your confirmation by Wednesday at the latest that the documentation will be issued to the best of your ability.                 If I do not hear from you by the end of the day on Wednesday, I will issue my client's letter of indemnity.                 Kind regards,                 Luis Perez
Email 3:
I am contacting you to discuss the concerns I have regarding the issues on the cruise.              Despite the itinerary on the website stating that a 5 hour lunch break would be given in the day time, this was not the case. Our client's cruise began early in the morning, and at the start of the first afternoon, the cruise stopped for an hour, where the client's lunch would have been normally taken.                Following this, our client informed the cruise company that she would not be able to attend any additional activities during the second part of the cruise, due to her trip abroad the next morning.                Unfortunately, after the cruise stopped, the client left to change her outfit for dinner. It is clear to me that her actions were not entirely justified. However, what can I do as the representative of our client?              I feel that the cruise company must compensate the client for the disappointment of
output_text:
From: margarita.madison@shipping.com
To: luis.perez@trading.com
Subject: Documentation Requirements - Funchal Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Luis,

It has been brought to my attention that you will be handling the documentation for our client at Funchal next month. I must inform you that we can only guarantee completion of 50% of the documentation requirements, particularly regarding notices of loads and demurrage documentation. We will not be able to accept responsibility for any additional costs that may arise from this situation.

If you would like to discuss this matter further, please don't hesitate to contact me.

Best wishes,
Margarita Madison

---

From: luis.perez@trading.com
To: margarita.madison@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Documentation Requirements - Funchal Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 09:15
Body: Dear Margarita,

I am concerned to hear that the documentation will not be complete. This situation could cause significant complications on the sailing date and place undue pressure on our client, which is unacceptable.

I must emphasize that all required documentation needs to be issued as previously discussed. This is essential to protect our client's interests.

Please confirm by Wednesday that you will provide all necessary documentation to the best of your ability. If I do not receive your confirmation by end of day Wednesday, I will have no choice but to issue our client's letter of indemnity.

Kind regards,
Luis Perez

---

From: margarita.madison@shipping.com
To: luis.perez@trading.com
Subject: Re: Documentation Requirements - Funchal Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 15:45
Body: Dear Luis,

I am writing to address additional concerns regarding our cruise client's experience.

The published itinerary indicated a 5-hour lunch break, which was not provided. Instead, the cruise began early morning with only a one-hour stop in the early afternoon. Our client subsequently informed the cruise company that she would not participate in the remaining activities due to international travel commitments the following day.

While I acknowledge that the client's decision to leave for a wardrobe change during dinner time may not have been fully justified, as their representative, I believe some form of compensation should be considered for the significant deviation from the advertised schedule.

Best regards,
Margarita Madison

(I)   Noname goods description                      (J)   CIF Rotterdam loading FOB Karachi payment                     Best Regards,                    Ahmet TUR

In addition, terminal demurrage is also calculated based on the days the vessel remains alongside and/or in any accessible waters, and by the number of TEUs still berthed on the vessel." ship is not stuck in port for any longer than necessary for whatever reason and therefore, will want to

From: simon.chen@trading.com
To: turner.j@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Demurrage Charges Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 09:30
Body: Hi Mr. Turner,

I received your email regarding soybean shipment 2607 from Singapore to Hampton Roads, Virginia, with a demurrage charge of $13,500. However, I am actually inquiring about a different order - our 4th order of 3,000MT of automobile gas from Singapore to Kandla, with 45 days laytime, which has a demurrage charge of $3,500. I believe the difference in charges should be lower given the cargo size. Could you please clarify?

Thank you very much,
Simon

---

From: turner.j@shipping.com
To: simon.chen@trading.com
Subject: Re: Demurrage Charges Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 14:45
Body: Dear Simon,

Thank you for your email. Let me clarify our terminal demurrage structure. The terminal charges are calculated on a per day per TEU basis at the rate of $5.00. Terminal demurrage is calculated based on both the vessel's time alongside/in accessible waters and the number of TEUs still berthed on the vessel.

Could you please confirm if you need clarification on the charges based on the duration in Singapore or the cargo weight (MT)?

Best regards,
J. Turner

---

From: simon.chen@trading.com
To: turner.j@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Demurrage Charges Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-08-16 10:15
Body: Dear Mr. Turner,

Thank you for your response. I have several questions regarding the demurrage calculations:

1. Is there a minimum time frame for the ship's stay in Singapore?
2. What would be the demurrage for 3,000MT of automobile gas?
3. What would be the demurrage for 6,000MT?
4. What would be the demurrage for 15,000MT?
5. What would be the demurrage for 24,000MT?

Best regards,
Simon

---

From: simon.chen@trading.com
To: turner.j@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Demurrage Charges Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-08-17 09:00
Body: Dear Mr. Turner,

Following up on my previous email, could you please specify the time required to clear the ship in Singapore based on my order weight? Would it be 5, 7, 10, or 15 days?

Thank you,
Simon

---

From: turner.j@shipping.com
To: simon.chen@trading.com
Subject: Re: Demurrage Charges Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-08-17 15:30
Body: Dear Simon,

Thank you for your detailed inquiries. While I handled a similar case this morning where the vessel was to be cleared on August 21st with demurrage commencing from August 22nd, your case is different. For your small quantity order (3,000MT), the terminal demurrage should actually fall under the charterer's guarantee as per the charter party, not the seller's responsibility. This is standard for short-term bookings.

Best regards,
J. Turner

Email 2:
[...]
My dear friend!        Hello Martin,        [...] 
Let me tell you a little story! When I was a young boy, my father would regularly take me to the harbour where we would buy a shiny new fishing boat. I can still remember vividly how excited we were about the boat. I even drew my own boat on the beach, before we took it for a spin. I'm sure you can imagine how sad I was when my father came back, covered in blood! The poor boy (in my boat) couldn't swim! My father managed to catch the boy and somehow held onto the rope to the boat until the boy calmed down enough to reach for the rope. We are both thankful that the boat didn't sink. I tell you this story because I feel I have had a similar experience with this project. At first I had grand plans, and a shiny

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Ms. Chao,                    I have received your quotation, but would like to get an extra day as load restrictions will prevent us from sailing immediately. Do you have a best rate for 10,500MT of ethanol ready from Aqaba to Busan. It can only sail in 4 days time.                    Thank you,                    Jan
Email 2:
Hello Jan,                    We will schedule sailing of our VLCC bulker before the middle of next week. For the moment we don't have an extra day, but we can make an extra day at very short notice.                    In case we have a day available, we can let you know in advance. However, I think that you can get a best rate without the extra day.                    Also note that we always appreciate your cooperation in the necessary load procedure for loading VLCC cargoes on board. We have received several vessels from Busan with less than 100% ballast. We really have to reduce ballast with our last vessel to make sure to have sufficient load margins for the remaining cargo. That's our only excuse to load not the minimum ballast for our chemical vessel.                    Please be advised that if you have a cargo which will arrive close to expiry and consequently has to be held
Email 3:
Hello Felix,                Thank you for your latest information. However the tanks are already loaded with a cargo (last gas cargo) of 80% and will hold until the next load. Do you have a suitable rate for now?                Best regards,                Jan
Reply Email:
Dear Mr. Jan,                I can only give you a best rate if I know your cargo characteristics. But I think that you will have a lower rate if we let our bunker take care of your voyage. We will carry your product to Busan on a confirmed VLCC Bulker (per your request) and bunker from Busan to Aqaba. After that, you can pay bunker or proceed yourself. You will have to add discount of bunker oil at Busan.            If you wish, I can start our bunker and sailing arrangement in order to make an available space of approx. 5,500mt

I'll need your cargo specifications to provide the best rate. However, I can offer a solution where we handle the voyage on our VLCC, including bunkering from Busan to Aqaba. You would have the option to either pay for bunkers or arrange your own. A bunker discount at Busan would apply.

We can accommodate approximately 5,500MT if you'd like to proceed with this arrangement.

Please let me know if you would like me to begin the bunker and sailing arrangements.

Best regards,
Linda

<Email 3>:

I have shipped a container of cricket equipment from Brisbane and I need to know whether you can pick it up from the port. I’ll need you to help me out with the clearance as well. Andrea

Comments:

I’ve taken your advise and hired a local customs agent to get the cricket equipment cleared. I’ve also made arrangements to pick up my container from the port. The agent has told me that I must clear the equipment in a few days, otherwise the container may be sold. He also said that it’s a good thing to have the cricket equipment cleared by a local customs agent. I will be flying to Quetta in 10 days and will be arriving at the port to pick up the container. The agent has told me that a truck will be provided to take the container to my address. I do have some questions.

1. How do you pay for the clearance?
2. Will the trucking company charge us a fee?
3. What if the container is full? I need to send all my cricket equipment but I’m not sure if I’ll be able to fit it
Email 4:
Hi Saroop,
1. How do you pay for the clearance?
If you are paying for clearance and the agent is going to handle it, I suggest you pay with a pre-paid card and keep the receipt. Once you’re in Quetta, the agent will pay for the fees and keep the receipt for their records. When you go to get your cricket equipment, you’ll pay the agent back and keep their receipt.

2. Will the trucking company charge us a fee?
3. What if the container is full? I need to send all my cricket equipment but I’m not sure if I’ll be able to fit it

As for fees, you should ask the agent to send a quote to you. Once you confirm the cost, you should pay the agent and they should file the paperwork. I suggest you ask for a copy of the quote for your records.

Saroop

From: andrea.smith@email.com
To: saroop.khan@email.com
Subject: Re: Cricket Equipment Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 15:45
Body: Hi Saroop,

Regarding your questions:

1. For clearance payments, I recommend using a pre-paid card and keeping all receipts. The agent will handle the fees initially, and you can reimburse them when you arrive in Quetta.

2. For trucking fees and other costs, ask the agent for a detailed quote before proceeding. Make sure to get everything in writing.

3. Regarding container capacity, you should discuss the dimensions with the shipping agent to ensure everything will fit.

Regards,
Andrea

7. EMAILS: DEPARTMENTS (INTERNSHIP, GUTTER, SHACK, OR OTHER)

An email consists of the following structure:

•    The sender (intern) = “Introduction” + “What the intern wants”

•    The receiver (internship, gutter, etc.) = “Re” + “Requst”

•    Either an official reply or a non-official reply (informal).          If it’s non-official reply (informal), it’s followed by the words “j/k”, followed by “in all seriousness”

>    Here’s the bottom-line: we didn’t send a reference to Greg.                 Also, by the way, there’s a “

To: james.mutebi@mutebigroup.com

Body: Hello James,

Best regards,
Isabelle

---

From: james.mutebi@mutebigroup.com
To: isabelle.chen@textile-corp.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Supply Inquiry - Port Sudan to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2015-09-15 14:45
Body: Dear Isabelle,

Thank you for your inquiry. You may contact Mr. Adebayouba Ayodeji in your office or call us directly in Lagos at +234-803-571-0994.

Mutebi Group Plc has been established since 1986 and is renowned for marketing local rice and cotton. Since 2011, we have expanded into cotton marketing, particularly serving reputable local spinning mill clients. We have developed an extensive network of registered cotton farmers in Benue, Kano, Jigawa and other Northern States, managing quality agricultural activities including farming and ginning.

Best regards,
James Mutebi

---

From: isabelle.chen@textile-corp.com
To: james.mutebi@mutebigroup.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Supply Inquiry - Port Sudan to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2015-09-16 10:15
Body: Dear James,

I am trying to reach Mr. Ayodeji. Could you please provide his email address?

I also have several questions:
- Do you provide after-sales service post-harvest?
- What is the average yield per hectare?
- Are you affiliated with any cotton gin facilities?
- Are you currently supplying to spinning mills in Nigeria?
- Do you have remaining capacity for the 2015/2016 season?
- How do you determine pricing for different cotton types?

Looking forward to your response.

Best regards,
Isabelle

---

From: michael.adebayo@mutebigroup.com
To: isabelle.chen@textile-corp.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Supply Inquiry - Port Sudan to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2015-09-16 15:30
Body: Dear Isabelle,

I am Michael Adebayo, working with Mr. Ayodeji Adebayouba, our Regional General Manager. You can reach me at michael@outlook.com or +2348054092947.

Best regards,
Michael Adebayo

---

From: ayodeji.adebayouba@mutebigroup.com
To: isabelle.chen@textile-corp.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Supply Inquiry - Port Sudan to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2015-09-17 09:00
Body: Dear Isabelle,

Thank you for your interest in our cotton farming operations. We have established partnerships with experienced cotton farmers in Benue State and offer long-term partnership opportunities to investors and customers.

Our partners gain access to our farming base and production statistics. Currently, we achieve an average cotton yield of about 900kg/acre, with expectations to reach 1,800kg/acre.

Best regards,
Ayodeji Adebayouba

Email 5:

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Arina,                    Could you please send your ethanol availability for our voyage from Santos to Sao Paulo on February 1st? Please include a full schedule, including laytime.                    Sincerely,                    Marc
Email 2:
Dear Sir,
                     Please send me a full schedule and laytime, as you said.                       Regards,                    Your friend, Arina
 
# Glossary
 
**Stakeholders:** 
Those parties who have an interest in the outcome of a project or process.
 
**Communication:** 
Interaction between members in a group (or groups) that are involved in a process.

A laytime, also known as a layday, is a period of time agreed between a vessel and a port authorities, specifying when a ship is not at work. This is normally specified in terms of working hours and is common practice in global trade.
Email 3:
```
Dear Sir,
Please send me a full schedule and laytime, as you said.
Regards,
Your friend, Arina
```

input_text:
Email 1:
Mr. Swanson,                    I am sending you 3,400MT of barley from Colombo to Hamburg. I can finalize the rate for you in two days if you are interested.                    Do you have space next week?                    Best,                    Annie
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Swanson,               Thanks a lot for your kind reply. I would be happy to accept your offer if you would like to make it a little bit more flexible by allowing a variance of +/- 10 %.
                                  Unfortunately I don't have space for the delivery at the moment but next week I should have 3,500MT available.
                                  Do you think you can please send me some competitive rate offers for an immediate delivery?              This would be highly appreciated.
                                  Yours truly,                    Annie

Response to the email from the client:
Dear Mrs. Flaherty,               Thank you for your proposal, unfortunately our company has no immediate availability. But I can make a proposal as soon as I can locate some stock.
                                  Yours truly,                    Annie

In this email scenario, Annie sent a request to the client. In the email, she included the deadline for the request,
output_text:
From: annie.flaherty@tradingco.com
To: swanson@shippingline.com
Subject: Barley Shipment Inquiry - Colombo to Hamburg
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:30
Body: Mr. Swanson,

I am inquiring about shipping 3,400MT of barley from Colombo to Hamburg. I can provide you with final rates within two days if you are interested.

Do you have vessel space available next week?

Best regards,
Annie

---

From: swanson@shippingline.com
To: annie.flaherty@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Barley Shipment Inquiry - Colombo to Hamburg
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:45
Body: Dear Mrs. Flaherty,

Thank you for your inquiry. Unfortunately, we have no immediate vessel availability. I will contact you with a proposal once I can locate suitable capacity.

Yours truly,
Mr. Swanson

---

From: annie.flaherty@tradingco.com
To: swanson@shippingline.com
Subject: Re: Barley Shipment Inquiry - Colombo to Hamburg
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 16:20
Body: Dear Mr. Swanson,

Thank you for your prompt reply. I would be open to a +/- 10% variance in cargo size, and I note that next week I will have space for up to 3,500MT.

If possible, could you please provide some competitive rate offers for immediate delivery when space becomes available?

Yours truly,
Annie
