input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Mr. Kamhi,                    We are currently working on a 6,000MT cargo of acid anhydride from New Orleans to Saudi Arabia, and can you provide a standard rate if we finalize on Tuesday?                    Thanks,                    Bobby
Email 2:
Hi Bobby,
 
It will cost $25 per MT, FOB New Orleans.
The freight rates for the 40' FP container would be about $1400.
The ocean freight could be spread over 16 weeks, so I would expect to see your cargo 16 weeks from now, if I do not get an early payment for the freight. 
 
However, the standard practice here is to allow the buyer to get a spot rate, which, I have noted, is 28% higher than our price.
The seller is hoping to make the spot rate, but does not have the luxury of counting on it.
The buyer might not find a spot rate, or might not be able to pay for it.
So, that is why I am asking you to call me on Tuesday and get a standard price. 
 
Let me know if you need any further information.

Best regards,                    Ron
Email 3:
Hi Ron,                    Thanks for your email.                    I will forward this to the client.                    Hope to hear from you later.                    Regards,                    Bobby

Could you also let us know how the temperature of your tanks are for each of the export destinations?                    Regards,                    Sunny
Email 2:
Hi Sunny!                    2,500MT of corn oil from Northfleet sounds like a job for us. Our tanks are at normal temperature for all of our destinations except for the north of England which we will deliver from a normal temperature tank. Your cargo will need to be offloaded on the 7th October and delivered on the 12th October. We will be able to give you the exact location of the delivery on the day of the cargo.                    We will contact you with a freight quote as soon as possible.                    Regards,                    Jade

3. Options for processing emails: Email providers such as GMail, Yahoo and Hotmail automatically delete emails older than 30 days. Email servers such as Microsoft Exchange store emails for 30 days and delete them after that period of time.

1. Images are important for personalizing the email and increase the open rate of the email
    2. Each and every email requires a proper introduction so that the reader won’t ignore the email in the first glance
    3. Many people find opening emails with text that start with the word ‘Please’ to be annoying and just delete the email without reading it
    4. Each email is a reflection of the client’s brand so every email should have the client’s brand information
    5. It is better to write less, but write better so that it remains simple and easier for the reader to understand

input_text:
Email 1:
Good morning Patrick.                    We are currently moving 12,500MT of urea from Dubai to Jakarta next month. Could you advise if we will have to take a full vessel to transport this amount?                    Best regards,                    Penny
Email 2:
Hello Penny,
    It depends on the vessel being used and the type of material being loaded.
    When you move 12500mt in a single shipment, there are some factors that affect this amount as well:
    1) Max. Weight of each vessel, which depends on the type of vessel (tanker, lighthouse, etc.)
    2) The “type” of material that you are transporting and their density.
    3) The amount of space you are occupying in each “stack” (which can range from one to five depending on the type of vessel and its design)
    So, basically, you should consider that for every ton of material you move you can load a specific amount of empty spaces available (which is determined by the vessel’s design and type) in order to have a full “load” but it’s not a guarantee that you will fill all
Email 3:

output_text:
From: penny.roberts@trading.com
To: patrick.wilson@shipping.com
Subject: Urea Shipment Dubai to Jakarta - Vessel Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Good morning Patrick,

We are currently moving 12,500MT of urea from Dubai to Jakarta next month. Could you advise if we will have to take a full vessel to transport this amount?

Best regards,
Penny

---

From: patrick.wilson@shipping.com
To: penny.roberts@trading.com
Subject: Re: Urea Shipment Dubai to Jakarta - Vessel Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hello Penny,

It depends on the vessel being used and the type of material being loaded. When moving 12,500MT in a single shipment, several factors need to be considered:

1. Maximum weight capacity of the vessel, which varies by vessel type
2. The physical properties of the urea and its stowage factor
3. The vessel's cargo hold configuration and stack capacity

For this quantity, you might not need a full vessel - we could potentially arrange for a parcel booking on a larger bulk carrier. Would you like me to explore some specific options?

Best regards,
Patrick

output_text:
From: jade.smith@tradingco.com
To: operations@portservices.com
Subject: Anthracite Coal Shipment - West Bengal to Kuching
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 09:15
Body: Good morning,

We're looking at 4,100MT of anthracite coal shipment from West Bengal to Kuching. Could you please confirm your demurrage rate and the weekend berth restrictions, and would you anticipate receiving a lumpsum freight quote?

Regards,
Jade

---

From: operations@portservices.com
To: jade.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Anthracite Coal Shipment - West Bengal to Kuching
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 10:30
Body: Morning,

Thank you for your email.

The demurrage charges for your requirement would be USD 10 per day subject to the ICD storage fee. We will require a two-week clearance. We can provide you with a lump sum quote for this requirement upon receipt of the details including your FCO, B/L details, and DCS information.

Your samples for coal testing can be shipped along with the main consignment, or you can instruct us to receive the sample at the ICD and do a pickup from the ICD itself. Please note that we are unable to open your samples at the ICD itself. This can be done at the port facility where your shipment is due to be loaded onto the vessel.

Your vessel would have a berth from 26 July – 3 August. Therefore, we will be able to load your shipment between these dates.

Best regards,
Operations Team

---

From: jade.smith@tradingco.com
To: operations@portservices.com
Subject: Re: Anthracite Coal Shipment - West Bengal to Kuching
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 11:45
Body: Thank you for your prompt response.

Could you please provide the additional information? Are you able to process the cargo under my terms & conditions? Are you able to send the terms & conditions via email? How can I send you the completed quotation?

Regards,
Jade

---

From: operations@portservices.com
To: jade.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Anthracite Coal Shipment - West Bengal to Kuching
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 13:20
Body: Thanks Jade for your prompt response,

It's my pleasure to provide you the requested information:

The sample testing will be done at the port facility where the cargo is due to be loaded. We will need to have a sample FCO for each item we are receiving. When the cargo is tested, we will only have the test report for each item, we will be unable to know the quantity of each item separately. The invoice for the samples will be generated as a separate invoice from the main cargo invoice.

Regarding terms and conditions, we will send these separately for your review.

Best regards,
Operations Team

Please let me know if you need any additional information.

Regards,
Prince

Subject: Diesel Shipment Inquiry - Venezuela to Rotterdam
Timestamp: 2024-07-01 09:15
Body: Hello M/s Alex,

I need to schedule a shipment of 3,200MT of diesel from Venezuela to Rotterdam. I have 8 deliveries planned from July 15 to Aug 1. How much is your deposit? Do you prefer payment by wire transfer or cash?

Looking forward to your reply,
Tal

---

From: alex.broker@freightco.com
To: tal.shipper@company.com
Subject: Re: Diesel Shipment Inquiry - Venezuela to Rotterdam
Timestamp: 2024-07-01 11:30
Body: Hi Tal,

Thank you for the inquiry. We will be glad to proceed with your request. Our minimum deposit is US$100,000 per shipment. Since you are requesting 8 shipments, the total deposit required would be US$800,000, payable in 8 installments of US$100,000 each.

This deposit will be deducted from the total value of your shipments. For example, if you are shipping 3,200MT of diesel at US$500 per MT, the total cost would be US$1,600,000. The US$800,000 deposit would be deducted from this amount.

The advance payment requirement serves as a guarantee for your shipment and our freight charges.

Best regards,
Alex

---

From: alex.broker@freightco.com
To: tal.shipper@company.com
Subject: Re: Diesel Shipment Inquiry - Venezuela to Rotterdam
Timestamp: 2024-07-01 14:45
Body: Hi Tal,

I apologize if there was any misunderstanding regarding the deposit amount. We require a higher deposit than usual due to the short notice and multiple shipments involved. Our forwarders are quite risk-averse and have limited resources, with most of their capital tied up in freight operations. They cannot take chances on shipments without adequate security.

I hope you understand our position.

Best regards,
Alex

Thanks for your inquiry on our weekly market updates.                           Generally, we don't add any detention charges for early deliveries to Ningbo as the available vessels are very tight. To summarize our market, we hope this information helps you.
                              Yours sincerely,
                              Cheryl

## Mixtures of positive and negative numbers

How many of these below have positive and negative numbers?

Negative, negative, negative
Positive, positive, positive
Positive, negative, negative
Negative, positive, positive

For the last one, why is it true?

Consider the following:

4 + (-2) + 1 + (-3)
4 - 2 + 1 + (-3)
(-4) + (-2) + 1 + (-3)
(-4) + (-2) - 1 + (-3)

The resulting numbers can be either positive or negative. This is a property of addition that is

input_text:
Email 1:
This is Mr. Herron.                    For 3,000MT of rapeseed from Hamburg to Nizhny Novgorod, do you have any vessels to dispatch between March 8-12?                    Can you please send a proposal with demurrage in 3 days?                    Many thanks,                    Ursula
Email 2:
To Mr. Herron,                    Thanks for your proposal.                    We are not shipping yet and I need some more time before we will decide.                    2 weeks is enough time?                    Thank you,                    Christian

<Email 3>:
To Mr. Herron,                    Thank you for the proposal.                    I had a look and decided not to book.                    Greetings,                    Christian

This example is based on real emails that I've received. I've written these 3 emails to illustrate how email communication between companies works in practice.
Email 3:
To Mr. Herron,                    Thank you for the proposal.                    I had a look and decided not to book.                    Greetings,                    Christian

This example is based on real emails that I've received. I've written these 3 emails to illustrate how email communication between companies works in practice.

<Email 3>:
 This is the first example.

  - Contact information for the company receiving the proposal (Name, Address, Email).
  - The reference number of the email (customer needs to refer to the source email of the proposal).
  - The reference number of the proposal (customer needs to refer to the proposal to be able to mention this on the shipper's proposal).
  - The subject line of the email (customer needs to refer to the subject of the email to be able to find the email).
  - The date and time when the email is sent.
  - The greeting used by the customer (which the customer would use to greet the shipper).
  - The body of the email.

Each line can be customized using the settings in the Customer Proposal Email.
Email 2:
This is the second example.

  - Contact information for the company receiving the proposal (Name, Address, Email

Email 1:
Hi!                    We’d like to move 6,000MT of liquid sugar to Surabaya, in a 27,000MT Heavy lift/Project cargo Carrier. Do you have availability for load by the 20th, and when is your earliest demurrage structure?                    Thank you for your time.                    Brian
Email 2:
Dear Brian, 
Thanks for your enquiry. Unfortunately we do not have any availability for cargo for the 20th of June. There is a Bunker Bill due for our vessels, which is expected to be paid by the 13th of June and must be settled for our vessel to load and depart from the US. The earliest we would be available would be on the 25th of June. 

As for demurrage, we would like to discuss this with you as the amount and structure of demurrage is not fixed. Our rates start from USD1.00 /ft per day, for which the terms are: 

      Shipowner's Demurrage Policy

        A) FOB Conditions : Shipowner's Demurrage Rates : 
US$ 1.00 per cubic foot per day, subject to maximum
annual rate per cubic foot of US$ 75
Email 3:
Sorry Brian. After a quick review of our schedule, there are no available slots until August. 
Thanks and best regards, 
Katie

Assessment: You need to assess how to determine the carrier’s schedule, whether or not the carrier was using ocean carriers to establish the most economical solution or the schedules and deadlines and when the ship owner’s demurrage is going to be paid.

It is the purpose of emails to coordinate, communicate, and conduct business. This section examines a sample of email threads between buyers and sellers. In many ways, email resembles face-to-face conversations, which were analyzed in the last section.

Emails are more asynchronous than face-to-face conversations. While email conversations allow for a lot of discussion, they are also prone to misunderstandings, miscommunication, and misinterpretation. Email users can only respond to a message when they receive it, but in the process of email composition, it takes a lot of time before a response is sent. Communication between two email users is often delayed and incomplete. Also, email messages are prone to re-read

Good day,                    Could you kindly confirm the latest market price for CFCL grades 54,55 and 56?                    Thank you for your attention,                    Liana
Email 2:
Hi Mr. Tanoov                 The latest market price for CFCL 54,55, and 56 is 40.49/bl., but the prices were updated on 26th Nov.                    Kindly be informed that we have stopped importing grade CFCL, and this material is now available only on request.                    Please reach me at your convenience for any further assistance.                    Thank you for your understanding.                    Antal Khilko

<Email 3>:
Good day Mr. Khilko             I am so disappointed that CFCL is not available. I was counting on purchasing this material for my project and do not have any other options. I may be able to find an alternative but the ones available are more expensive.                    If you have any recommendations regarding these materials or possible sources where CFCL is available, please share the information with me.                    Thank you for your attention
Email 3:
Good day Mr. Khilko             I am so disappointed that CFCL is not available. I was counting on purchasing this material for my project and do not have any other options. I may be able to find an alternative but the ones available are more expensive.                    If you have any recommendations regarding these materials or possible sources where CFCL is available, please share the information with me.                    Thank you for your attention

<Email 3>:
 Dear Liana,                    Thank you for your message and please accept my apologies for the inconvenience.                    Unfortunately, the price for CFCL is not the only reason we decided to stop importing this material.                    As you know, with the growing production of carbon fiber products, the supply of CFCL has become more limited, and it has become more difficult to secure it.                    Also, there are no warehouses in the USA that are licensed to store this product.                    Therefore, in order to ensure the quality of this material, and not to damage it during transportation, we have stopped importing CFCL.                    On the other hand, the price of other types of composites is increasing, and CFCL has become relatively more expensive.                    Nevertheless, you are always welcome to reach out to us with your requirements, and we will be more than happy to help you find the best alternative for your project.
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Tanoov.                 I will start my project this Monday and would like to place an order immediately for the quantities I need. Where can I get technical data sheets for these materials? As I understand it, CFCL 55 and 56 are available in two variants, with a different thickness. Is it correct?                    Thank you for your attention.                    Lucie

Email 4:

From: liana.tanoov@company.com
To: antal.khilko@canamyte.com
Subject: CFCL Price Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-11-28 09:15
Body: Good day,

Could you kindly confirm the latest market price for CFCL grades 54, 55 and 56?

Thank you for your attention,
Liana

---

From: antal.khilko@canamyte.com
To: liana.tanoov@company.com
Subject: Re: CFCL Price Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-11-28 10:30
Body: Hi Mr. Tanoov,

The latest market price for CFCL 54, 55, and 56 is 40.49/bl., but the prices were updated on 26th Nov.

Kindly be informed that we have stopped importing grade CFCL, and this material is now available only on request.

Please reach me at your convenience for any further assistance.

Thank you for your understanding.

Antal Khilko

---

From: liana.tanoov@company.com
To: antal.khilko@canamyte.com
Subject: Re: CFCL Price Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-11-28 11:45
Body: Good day Mr. Khilko,

I am so disappointed that CFCL is not available. I was counting on purchasing this material for my project and do not have any other options. I may be able to find an alternative but the ones available are more expensive.

If you have any recommendations regarding these materials or possible sources where CFCL is available, please share the information with me.

Thank you for your attention

---

From: antal.khilko@canamyte.com
To: liana.tanoov@company.com
Subject: Re: CFCL Price Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-11-28 13:20
Body: Dear Liana,

Thank you for your message and please accept my apologies for the inconvenience.

Unfortunately, the price for CFCL is not the only reason we decided to stop importing this material. As you know, with the growing production of carbon fiber products, the supply of CFCL has become more limited, and it has become more difficult to secure it.

Also, there are no warehouses in the USA that are licensed to store this product. Therefore, in order to ensure the quality of this material, and not to damage it during transportation, we have stopped importing CFCL.

On the other hand, the price of other types of composites is increasing, and CFCL has become relatively more expensive.

Nevertheless, you are always welcome to reach out to us with your requirements, and we will be more than happy to help you find the best alternative for your project.

Best regards,
Antal Khilko

---

From: lucie@company.com
To: antal.khilko@canamyte.com
Subject: CFCL Specifications and Price List
Timestamp: 2023-11-29 09:00
Body: Dear Mr. Khilko,

I will start my project this Monday and would like to place an order immediately for the quantities I need. Could you please provide an updated price list, as well as the specifications for CFCL 54/55 and 56?

I have a question for you. Where can I get technical data sheets for these materials? As I understand it, CFCL 55 and 56 are available in two variants, with a different thickness. Is it correct?

Thank you for your attention.
Lucie

- Container Service: $8,300
- Air Freight: $13,000

We work with several trusted carrier partners and will ensure you receive the most competitive rates, especially if you choose air freight.

Please let me know if you need any additional information.

Best regards,
Clara

input_text:
Email 1:
Can your vsl lift 8,400MT of clinker from Sohar to Mombasa? Also, do you apply a bunker escalation clause or keep a fixed rate?                    Regards,                    Andrew
Email 2:
Due to the complexity of bulk rates, both simple and indexed escalation clauses are commonly used in the
sea cargo market. Bulk rates are based on bunker price and tonnage. Escalation clauses are used to
implement the benefits of a bunker cost increase and prevent the carrier from changing the contract rate
and extending it through an escalation clause. Generally, escalation clauses are used when a contract
purchaser is concerned about the impact of a bunker price increase. Should the bunker price increase,
bulk rates and contracts are usually adjusted accordingly. A bunker escalation clause allows the parties
to index their contracts on a timely basis rather than having to wait until a contract is being renewed or
terminated. In addition, an escalation clause in a contract increases the incentive for the parties to
achieve cost savings by allowing the buyer to negotiate an adjustment when the seller is benefiting from
a rise in the cost
output_text:
From: andrew.smith@shipper.com
To: operations@carrier.com
Subject: Clinker Shipment Inquiry - Sohar to Mombasa
Timestamp: 2024-02-14 09:30
Body: Can your vessel lift 8,400MT of clinker from Sohar to Mombasa? Also, do you apply a bunker escalation clause or keep a fixed rate?

Regards,
Andrew

---

From: operations@carrier.com
To: andrew.smith@shipper.com
Subject: Re: Clinker Shipment Inquiry - Sohar to Mombasa
Timestamp: 2024-02-14 11:45
Body: Dear Andrew,

Thank you for your inquiry. Regarding the bunker clause, we typically use an escalation clause for bulk cargo contracts. This allows us to adjust rates based on bunker price fluctuations, providing more flexibility than fixed rates. The clause enables regular indexing of contract rates without waiting for contract renewal, while protecting both parties from significant bunker price variations.

Regarding vessel availability and specific rate quotation, could you please provide your intended laycan dates?

Best regards,
Operations Team

Email 1:
We plan to ship 8,500MT of glycerine from Hamburg to Qingdao. Please advise the load density, and lumpsum rate, and if you have a vessel suited for this cargo type.                    Regards,                    Sebastian
Email 2:
I am selling below DTC of your original request. Cargo will be sailed in Dec 2015. Kindly confirm the forwarder number.                   Regards,
                   DTC




<Email 3>:
As per your request details are mentioned below. Please contact our forwarder or directly to us.                       Regards,
                   DTC


Here, we have a business email communication where a shipping company is seeking to ship glycerine and is inquiring about suitable vessel. We first receive a generic email with a request to send quote details from the customer. Then they provide us with additional details, which we quote, and finally send back our quotation to the customer along with additional information. Once everything is satisfactory we receive confirmation from the customer for the shipment. The customer also provides details about the forwarder as well as the final rates.
Email 3:
As per your request details are mentioned below. Please contact our forwarder or directly to us.                       Regards,
                   DTC


Here, we have a business email communication where a shipping company is seeking to ship glycerine and is inquiring about suitable vessel. We first receive a generic email with a request to send quote details from the customer. Then they provide us with additional details, which we quote, and finally send back our quotation to the customer along with additional information. Once everything is satisfactory we receive confirmation from the customer for the shipment. The customer also provides details about the forwarder as well as the final rates.

<Email 3>:
 Dear Sir,

               We shall not send any formal quotation, since our DTC (Direct to Customer) rates are now becoming lower, even than some of our regular global agents. We would require forwarder details, if you have one in mind. Also please confirm, when the vessel, loaded with glycerine, will be sailing out, as we want to have this booked in advance, so as to avoid any problems later on.

                               Regards,
                            DTC



A sample query for a price quote from a client is mentioned here. The client has requested the DTC rate for the shipment and the corresponding cargo details are mentioned along with their specifications. The prices, which are normally sent by the company, are priced according to the total value of the goods being transported, the volume of the shipment, and the weight of the goods, and also if the cargo is being sent as a container

input_text:
Email 1:
Good afternoon Mr. Gualtieri,                    I’m emailing to check the status of our order for 12,900MT of steel plates from Rotterdam to El País. We’re currently experiencing an issue with customs clearance and would like to find out how you’re dealing with this in the meantime.                    We would appreciate an email back as soon as possible.                    Regards,                    Greg
Email 2:
Thank you for your email regarding our port clearance issues.                    Unfortunately, we haven’t been able to clear our shipment through customs due to COVID-19. We understand that this is due to increased security measures put in place by the government.                    To ensure we are fully compliant with all necessary regulations, we will have to delay our delivery of your goods.                    Our records show that we have been in communication regarding this matter but would like to confirm that our progress is on track.                    If there is anything further you would like us to do in relation to this order or any other queries you may have, please do not hesitate to get in touch.                    Best Regards,                    Rob
output_text:
From: greg.smith@trading.com
To: r.gualtieri@steelco.com
Subject: Steel Plates Order Status - Customs Clearance Issue
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:32
Body: Good afternoon Mr. Gualtieri,

I'm emailing to check the status of our order for 12,900MT of steel plates from Rotterdam to El País. We're currently experiencing an issue with customs clearance and would like to find out how you're dealing with this in the meantime.

We would appreciate an email back as soon as possible.

Regards,
Greg

---

From: r.gualtieri@steelco.com
To: greg.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Steel Plates Order Status - Customs Clearance Issue
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 16:45
Body: Dear Greg,

Thank you for your email regarding our port clearance issues.

Unfortunately, we haven't been able to clear our shipment through customs due to COVID-19. We understand that this is due to increased security measures put in place by the government.

To ensure we are fully compliant with all necessary regulations, we will have to delay our delivery of your goods. Our records show that we have been in communication regarding this matter but would like to confirm that our progress is on track.

If there is anything further you would like us to do in relation to this order or any other queries you may have, please do not hesitate to get in touch.

Best Regards,
Rob

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Bernard,                    Does Dry Ports exist in Vietnam? I need to send around 4,000kgs of auto parts from HCMC to Dalat, just passing through. Any idea what would be the charges?                    Thank you,                    Jack
Email 2:
Dear Jack,                       Thank you for your email, indeed we have dry ports in Vietnam. Vietnam does have an import office called Sava.                         The office of Sava is in Hai Phong port. The service charge for Sava is 100usd per 40’ container. However, we don't have so many customers of Sava, since we don't provide special service of handling duty.                        If you have any other questions, please feel free to contact me.                        Thank you for your time.                       Sincerely yours,                        Bernard
Email 3:
Thanks Bernard, it sounds like we should not use Sava. Is the tariff $1,650 per container? The web site states $600 per container, but is that for everything we need to pay? Or just the charge for Sava? Thanks. Jack
Email 4:
Hi Bernard,   Thank you for your information.    The charges for your services looks reasonable, however, I still need to check for the final quotation and please give me the advise on that.    Also, I need to ask, is the term of payment 30% before shipping out the container, and the balance upon arrival to Cambodia? Thank you.

Hello Bernard,   Thanks again for the information on your services, however, I still need to check for the quotation, can you send me the PDF format on it?   Thanks.

Email 5:

<Email 6>:

<Email 5>:
 I have been looking up this information from various websites, including yours and I have come to the conclusion that we have to use Sava Customs clearance. Is that correct? If not, can you please give me an alternative? I have two cargo from my warehouse in Korea (Dong Ha Port) which I would like to send to Cambodia. Thanks
<Email 6>:
Hi Bernard,     Can you please give me an estimate on the costs for your services?    I also have some questions on it: 1- does the information that I gave you already, includes your services? If not, how much it will cost? 2- is the import duties excluded?     Thank you 
<Email 7>:
Dear Bernard,   Thanks for all your information on the services you can provide for us.    Can you please also tell me the time of loading the container in
output_text:
From: jack.smith@company.com
To: bernard.nguyen@logistics.vn
Subject: Inquiry about Dry Ports in Vietnam
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Bernard,

Does Vietnam have dry ports? I need to transport approximately 4,000kgs of auto parts from Ho Chi Minh City to Dalat. Could you please advise on the associated charges?

Thank you,
Jack

---

From: bernard.nguyen@logistics.vn
To: jack.smith@company.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Dry Ports in Vietnam
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Jack,

Thank you for your inquiry. Yes, we do have dry ports in Vietnam. There is an import office called Sava, located at Hai Phong port. Their service charge is 100 USD per 40' container. However, please note that we have limited experience with Sava as we don't provide specialized customs duty handling services.

Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Sincerely,
Bernard

---

From: jack.smith@company.com
To: bernard.nguyen@logistics.vn
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Dry Ports in Vietnam
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Dear Bernard,

Thank you for the information. It seems Sava might not be the best option for us. I noticed some discrepancy in the pricing - the website shows $600 per container, but I've seen references to $1,650. Could you clarify if these amounts are all-inclusive or just Sava's charges?

Thanks,
Jack

---

From: jack.smith@company.com
To: bernard.nguyen@logistics.vn
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Dry Ports in Vietnam
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 09:15
Body: Dear Bernard,

The charges for your services seem reasonable, but I need a final quotation. Also, could you confirm if the payment terms are 30% before container shipment and the balance upon arrival in Cambodia?

Thank you,
Jack

---

From: jack.smith@company.com
To: bernard.nguyen@logistics.vn
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Dry Ports in Vietnam
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 15:30
Body: Dear Bernard,

Could you please send me the quotation in PDF format? Also, I've been researching and want to confirm if Sava customs clearance is mandatory for shipments from Korea (Dong Ha Port) to Cambodia.

Best regards,
Jack

From: chen.w@inlandwater.com
To: shipping@ministry.gov
Subject: A possible cargo for mid-June
Timestamp: 2023-05-01 09:30
Body: Dear Sir,

I would like to inquire about a possible cargo shipment for the mid-June window. This matter requires urgency and needs to be addressed within seven days.

Port of loading and draft specifications:
- Al Khobar: 15-16 meters
- Zeebrugge: 13.2 meters

Cargo details:
- Weight: 6,600MT of LSHS (Low Sulfur Heavy Stock)
- Discharge port: Port of Balikpapan (Balikpapan, Indonesia)
- Expected arrival: Mid-May 2023

Please provide your response at your earliest convenience.

Best regards,
Mr. Chen
Inland Water Transportation Corporation

---

From: chen.w@inlandwater.com
To: shipping@ministry.gov
Subject: RE: A possible cargo for mid-June
Timestamp: 2023-05-02 14:15
Body: Dear Sir,

I am following up as I haven't received any response to my previous email.

Regards,
Mr. Chen

---

From: chen.w@inlandwater.com
To: zee.r@ministry.gov
Subject: Canceled Suez transit for Balikpapan vessel
Timestamp: 2023-05-03 10:45
Body: Dear Mr. Zee,

In response to your email, I must inform you that the IMO regulations only permit Suez Canal transit within 24 hours after the loading of LSHS. This timeline is too restrictive for our scheduled sailing window to the Indies.

Best regards,
Mr. Chen
Manager, International Trade Department

---

From: zee.r@ministry.gov
To: chen.w@inlandwater.com
Subject: A cargo to the north of Borneo from Bangladesh
Timestamp: 2023-05-03 15:20
Body: Mr. Chen,

We are transporting a cargo to the northern part of Borneo from Bangladesh.

Regards,
Mr. Zee
Ministry of Foreign Affairs

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Karina,                    Thank you for the sul acid enquiry. As per our past experiences, most vessels from Antwerp take 10-12 days to arrive Houston. Also, most vessels will be full loaded for India with sulphuric acid as a ballast cargo, which will mean lower revenue for the vessel and therefore higher freight costs. I would recommend using a break-bulk vessel to optimise freight costs, especially given the uncertainty regarding international economic conditions. Please advise on your shipper requirements and if you would like a quotation.                    Kind regards,                    Jon
Email 2:
Dear Jon,                   Thank you for your response and the quote that you provided. The distance from India is 8,325 nautical miles. We will appreciate if you can kindly provide a detailed quotation for shipping one (1) unit (21.3 cubic meters) of sulphuric acid at 1.32 MW+ acid based on shipper specifications at a FCA Houston port.   Kind regards,                     Our attention: Jon, Adrian

Jon,                      Thanks for your follow up. I have received your updated enquiry and have already emailed it to our contact in India who will be able to provide you with a detailed quotation. Thank you,                        Jon

## SO2 Shipments

### Shipper info:

Freight Cost:           $10,500.00 Freight FCL:       1 CTN x 21.3 cubic meters @ 1.32
output_text:
From: jon.smith@freightbroker.com
To: karina.davis@client.com
Subject: RE: Sulphuric Acid Shipment Inquiry - Antwerp to Houston
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:30
Body: Hi Karina,

Thank you for the sulphuric acid enquiry. As per our past experiences, most vessels from Antwerp take 10-12 days to arrive Houston. Also, most vessels will be full loaded for India with sulphuric acid as a ballast cargo, which will mean lower revenue for the vessel and therefore higher freight costs.

I would recommend using a break-bulk vessel to optimise freight costs, especially given the uncertainty regarding international economic conditions. Please advise on your shipper requirements and if you would like a quotation.

Kind regards,
Jon

---

From: dan.peterson@trading.com
To: robby.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Quotation Request - Crude Oil Transport Port Louis to Toliara
Timestamp: 2009-01-30 09:15
Body: Good morning, Robby.

We would like to get a quotation for the transport of 10,000MT of crude oil from Port Louis to Toliara. This is a regular cargo from our company and we are looking forward to getting a reliable and punctual partner on this lane.

Can you give us an early estimate?

Warm regards,
Dan

---

From: robby.smith@shipping.com
To: dan.peterson@trading.com
Subject: Re: Quotation Request - Crude Oil Transport Port Louis to Toliara
Timestamp: 2009-01-30 11:30
Body: Hi Dan,

Thank you for your inquiry regarding crude oil transport from Port Louis to Toliara. I've confirmed with our team that we have a crew member in Port Louis and a vessel arriving on February 1st. We will be using our own cargo vessel for this transport.

I'll be meeting with my superior to finalize the details and will provide you with a complete quotation by the end of today.

Regards,
Robby

---

From: robby.smith@shipping.com
To: dan.peterson@trading.com
Subject: Re: Quotation Request - Crude Oil Transport Port Louis to Toliara
Timestamp: 2009-01-30 16:45
Body: Hi Dan,

Following our earlier correspondence, I'm pleased to provide you with our quotation:

Route: Port Louis - Toliara
Arrival Port: Port Louis
Departure Date: 2009-02-03
Voyage Duration: 7 days
Crew: 3 sailors (@ $4,000 per sailor)
VOCSURV(+) in La Reunion
Transport costs: $500 (0.5% per day × 10,000MT)

Total cost: $6,500

We will send you the formal invoice in PDF format shortly.

Kind regards,
Robby

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Mr. Johnson,                    We require a 36,000MT cargo of iron ore from Santos to Richards Bay. We’ve got a very strong buyer who wants a May delivery, could you commit to that?                    You mentioned your vessel has the capacity to do a 2-week voyage – is that the case?                    Best Regards,                    David
Email 2:
Dear Sir/Madam,                  We’re interested in trading iron ore with you. A friend of mine was recommended to me and I’ve been meaning to get in contact with you for a while now. Would you be free to speak to me about it?                  Thanks,                  John

### Current email sections:
* Your message, if you want to write one.
* Options to send the message.

### Best to reply by mail
> Correspondence from John, David and Alice
John has selected 2 weeks for his voyage duration, so you’ll reply to him with your best quote within 2 weeks. But why not send your quote to all 3 customers at once? Click the gear icon on the current messages to specify your pricing term.

> Going from A to B

He’s asked you for a quote, so you can easily fill in your lead time and calculate the exact date
Email 3:
Dear David,                  We can offer you a discount on our shipments, if you can book us an entire ship. For the capacity we’ve got (45,000MT), we can offer a 3% discount for early bookings.                Regards,                    Jenny

### Connecting voyages together

> Another option
Alice has left the details for her message in the same form as John. This means you can send a personalised quote and attach all the supporting documentation in one click.

### Note to self
> Have a look at your next message

This tab will help you keep track of your email conversations: see what messages you’ve seen and what you’re about to respond to.

> What next?
You can choose what you do next with the emails that have come in. See how you’ve done so far.

### Use an automated reply

Not sure if you can reply to this customer yet
Email 4:
We can offer you a discount on our shipments, if you can book us an entire ship. For the capacity we’ve got (45,000MT), we can offer a 3% discount for early bookings.                Regards,                    Jenny

Please have a look at your inbox for our last message. If we’re looking to book an entire ship, we can’t offer any discount. We’d like to hear back from you before our next message reaches you.

> We want to book an entire ship
Sending you this reply will prevent John and David from seeing it, so we can send a more personalised message.

> No more messages in draft

### You could reply with this message

You could reply with this message
Email 5:
Hello again. We can offer you a discount on our shipments, if you can book us an entire ship. For the capacity we’ve got (45,000MT), we can offer a 3% discount for early bookings.                Regards,                    Jenny

We have to send this message at the very last minute before the quote arrives. This is because we’ve agreed to trade iron ore, which we cannot do while John and David are in charge of this shipment. They will look at this message before receiving your next quote. You can see this by clicking your recent message, which you’ll find on the “previous message” button.

### Manage your previous messages

Looking at this message in your inbox will tell you everything you need to know, and even if John or David have replied. You can also open any message for a read-only view that will let you view attachments, mark as read

From: isabella.martinez@trading.com
To: gary.thompson@shipping.com
Subject: Soybean Shipment - Bunker Charges Query
Timestamp: 2023-07-17 09:15
Body: Hi Gary,

We are looking to ship 7,000MT of soybeans from New Orleans to Poland. Could you let me know what's the current bunker charges to Ashdod?

Regards,
Isabella

---

From: valentina.rogers@trading.com
To: gary.thompson@shipping.com
Subject: Re: [IN2-9985: Bid Request]
Timestamp: 2023-07-17 09:30
Body: Gary,

My client was recently asking how much we will need to pay for bunker charges from New Orleans to Ashdod for 7,000 MT of soybeans. I've already informed him that we would need to estimate the cost. Therefore, I would really appreciate if you could provide an estimate.

Thanks,
Valentina

---

From: gary.thompson@shipping.com
To: valentina.rogers@trading.com
Subject: Re: [IN2-9985: Bid Request]
Timestamp: 2023-07-17 09:45
Body: Hi Valentina,

The bunker costs to Ashdod from New Orleans are about $35/MT. This is based on the previous usage data that was compiled, so we can expect to see the actual bunker charges to be closer to that amount.

However, please be advised that we currently do not have that type of bunker data from Poland, so it is hard to know for sure without having access to the actual bunker records.

In any case, the information you received from the last time we discussed this scenario was likely an estimate.

Please let me know if you need any additional information.

Best regards,
Gary

# Bulk vs Loop – Top 5 SQL Performance Comparisons

### Bulk Update and Delete

The first bulk versus loop comparison is bulk update and delete operations. A bulk update or delete can be viewed as a more or less complicated data type conversion. Instead of processing rows with SELECT, UPDATE, or DELETE, one can convert them in bulk.

Bulk update and delete can be a lot faster than UPDATE and DELETE. While UPDATE and DELETE are based on changing one row at a time, a bulk update or delete can change or remove many rows at a time.

Let’s start with a simple UPDATE example.
```
UPDATE  table_name 
SET     field_name = 1.2

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Shipman,                    We have 3,000MT of pvc from Cucina to Hamburg. We also want to load 1,800MT of petc from Cucina to Jebel Ali. Can you provide an FOB rate for each leg?                    Thanks,                    Katie
Email 2:
I've got the FOB rate to the correct spots for you below.                    (Schedule and sea freight) (local contacts)                    Thanks,                    Tim


--------------- What is the output we want? ----------------

Given 2 emails, find a new third email that best describes the 2, and accurately provides the FOB rate to 2 correct locations. 

Assume that the `receiver` email is directly related to the `sender` email. 
Assume that any section of the new email that comes from the sender is already in the new email. 

It should look something like this:

I've got the FOB rate to the correct spots for you below. (Schedule and sea freight) (local contacts)

------------------------ Algorithm -------------------------

We will start with the (sender) email as our base for the new email. 

The goal is to take the `receiver` email and
Email 3:
* find the new email's content that can come from (receiver)
* find the section of new email content that matches (sender)
* find any additional content that comes from (sender)
* remove the unchanged content from (receiver)
* use `traversing` to take the two emails (sender, receiver) and find common topics
* save the parts of (receiver) that are unchanged and use those topics as a context
* grab the topic of (sender) that is already covered in (receiver) 
* find additional topics in (receiver) 
* if there are topics in (sender) that are not present in (receiver)
	* include the topics in the new email's content
	* don't change the original content (keep original content unchanged)
	* create a new paragraph that explains what the sender is asking the receiver to do
* add any context from
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Shipman,                    We have 3,000MT of pvc from Cucina to Hamburg. We also want to load 1,800MT of petc from Cucina to Jebel Ali. Can you provide an FOB rate for each leg?                    Thanks,                    Katie


What's still missing:

* email's content
* date
* frequency
* timezone
* number of emails
* table of email subject

Email 1:
Hi Rachel,                    I'm looking to move a cargo of oranges from Shanghai to Leixoes and want to know if you can provide me a reliable sea freight quote for this. Can I expect a same-day reply?                    Thanks,                    Chris
Email 2:
Hi Rachel,                    Please provide me a quote for a small cargo of boots and shoes from Kandahar to UK and I would expect an answer within a few hours at most.                    Thanks,                    Marianne

1. The emails will trigger two different responses (different offers to two different customers). For Email 1:
   We're sorry but we are not able to provide a reliable sea freight quote as we do not handle such shipments.
2. For Email 2:
   We do not deal with sea freight; can you please provide me a quote for air cargo?

   I will provide the following details in the email:

   a. From city/airport: Kandahar, Afghanistan
   b. To city/airport: London, UK
   c. Estimated weight: 100 kg
   d. Estimated dimensions: 20x15x10 cm
Email 3:
Hi Rachel,                    Please provide me a quote for shipping a pallet of apples from Mumbai to Venice and can I expect a same-day reply?                    Thanks,                    Daisy
   This will trigger one of the following two replies:

   a. We do not deal with such shipments; can you please contact our partner company L. Inc.?
   b. We do not have a pricing for fruit cargo; please contact our partner company L. Inc.

Subject: Cargo Inquiry - Concrete Blocks Denmark to Zurich
Timestamp: 2021-01-01 13:00
Body: Good morning,

I'm writing to you on behalf of a dear friend and colleague Mr. Rudolf Acers from Frankfurt. My colleague has been tasked to help arrange for the shipment of an unusual cargo – 30 x 2″ square concrete blocks from Denmark to Zurich.

Can you confirm whether you can handle this cargo, and what the minimum booking quantities might be?

I thank you for your time,

Ian

Blue Oar Maritime Limited
Phone: +41 100 000 000

---

From: inquiries@blueoar.com
To: ian.broker@blueoar.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry - Concrete Blocks Denmark to Zurich
Timestamp: 2021-01-01 14:00
Body: Dear Ian,

Thank you for your email regarding the concrete blocks shipment.

Kindly be informed that Blue Oar Maritime Ltd. can handle the cargo for you. The minimum quantity we can handle is 1 block.

Please advise when your friend can proceed with the booking and the estimated delivery dates to Zurich.

If you have any questions, kindly do not hesitate to contact us.

Best regards,
Blue Oar Maritime Ltd.

---

From: rudolf.acers@frankfurt.com
To: inquiries@blueoar.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry - Concrete Blocks Denmark to Zurich
Timestamp: 2021-01-01 15:00
Body: Dear Sir/Madam,

Thank you for your response to my colleague's query.

I'd be grateful if you could advise on the following:
1. If the blocks are packed in their own crates or in a common crate?
2. How many crates per shipment can be handled?

We appreciate your cooperation on this matter.

Best regards,
Mr. Acers

---

From: inquiries@blueoar.com
To: rudolf.acers@frankfurt.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry - Concrete Blocks Denmark to Zurich
Timestamp: 2021-01-01 17:30
Body: Dear Mr. Acers,

Regarding your questions:

1. The blocks will be packed in their own crates. There will be 30 x 2″ square concrete blocks per crate.
2. Blue Oar Maritime Ltd. can handle 30 crates per shipment.

We are preparing a detailed quotation for your review. This will be sent separately with our reference number RFRHBRK4787.

Best regards,
Blue Oar Maritime Ltd.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Atilano,                    We plan to lift 60,000MT of hand rolled paper from New Orleans to Vancouver in October. Would you offer flexible laycan dates to mitigate demurrage, or do you usually require 8 weeks between shipment and arrival?                    Best regards,                    Jesse
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Rich,                     No issue regarding demurrage on both sides, we can arrange any laycan for both ends.                     Thank you,                     Christina

Note: Both email 1 and email 2 are scanned from images of an actual shipment where both parties have entered into an email conversation about a particular shipment. In this case, email 1 is the first message to reach Ms. Christina who represents the company named "Singaporean Paper Mill" on behalf of their customer, a leading supplier of pulp and paper products.
Email 3:
Dear Christina,
We just received your email regarding our consignee would like to know the break bulk tariff on Paper Hand Rolled please send it to my email directly.                     
Best Regards, Jesse

Note: Email 3 is another example of a communication that actually was sent. In this case, the communication was sent to Ms. Christina directly, instead of to the company she represents. In many cases, the same "broken chain" appears, where the actual shipper contacts the recipient directly instead of using the channel of the NVOCC.
output_text:
From: jesse.rich@freightco.com
To: christina.atilano@singaporeanpaper.com
Subject: Paper Shipment Inquiry - NOLA to Vancouver

We plan to lift 60,000MT of hand rolled paper from New Orleans to Vancouver in October. Would you offer flexible laycan dates to mitigate demurrage, or do you usually require 8 weeks between shipment and arrival?

Best regards,
Jesse Rich

We have a 40,000MT shipment of xeno-glycerine (alcohol) from the port of Hamburg and are hoping to move the cargo by next week. Could you please advise a point of contact for your shipping agent to work with at the port of Halifax to get an arrival date for the shipment?                    Sincerely,                    Judy
Email 2:

We have a 40,000MT shipment of xeno-glycerine (alcohol) from the port of Hamburg and are hoping to move the cargo by next week. Could you please advise a point of contact for your shipping agent to work with at the port of Halifax to get an arrival date for the shipment?                    Regards,                    Judy

[ 26 July 2007 ]    MS OCEAN, departing Hamburg, Germany at 7:30pm, arrived Halifax at 7:30pm on July 26, 2007.                         MSC DELFINO, departing Hamburg, Germany at 10:30am, arrived Halifax at 7:30pm on July 29, 2007.                         MS THOM

We have a 40,000MT shipment of xeno-glycerine (alcohol) from the port of Hamburg and are hoping to move the cargo by next week. Sincerely,
Judy Schmidt

Best regards,
Rebecca Wey

Dear Shaikh,                    We have received a 5,600MT shipment of adhesives from Antwerp to Narva and a 3,600MT of yeast from Fos-sur-Mer to Antwerp. Could you please confirm your earliest loading date for both of them and do you offer a standard dispatch rate if we finish early?                    Looking forward to your reply.                    Kind regards,                    Aleksander
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Marczyk,                I am in receipt of your enquiry and thank you for giving us the opportunity to supply to your company. Both shipments were off-loaded on 3rd February from the vessel BARGE BRIGADE. After this we hold port-to-port (rORL) terms. We do not issue a standard dispatch rate, but would need to be informed of your earliest loading date to give you a shipping quotation. Please kindly contact us to this end.                Thank you for your attention.                Yours faithfully,                International Forwarding & Shipping GmbH                Tel. +49 221 84 07-40                  http://www.ifc-jade.de/en/index.php?id=63
Email 3:
Dearest Shaikh,                         I am sending you an invoice for $4,500 for services rendered in 2011. I will forward you an updated letter of credit for the payment.                     The company finances are not very good at the moment, so I have requested a further discount. I hope the courier will arrive with the updated letter of credit in the coming week.                     Thank you,                     Sincerely,                     Aleksander
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Marczyk,                I am in receipt of your correspondence of the 21st and the 30th of April, and kindly refer to our e-mail exchanges of the 15th, 19th and 21st of February.                According to our understanding of your request for a discount, you asked us to discount the amount as agreed on the 14th of February by 5% and paid the balance of the sum of $7,600.00 in Swiss francs to our bank account at the aforementioned date. Please be informed that we have received the payment of the amount of $3,200.00 in Swiss francs in our account on 14th of March 2011, and were not able to take a 5% discount on the sum, as the total amount in Swiss francs which were received in our account on 14th

Aleksander

Sincerely,
Aleksander

---

Yours faithfully,
IFC Shipping

input_text:
Email 1:
Good afternoon,                    Why do you tell us to listen to a song "Stairway to Heaven"? The lyrics are very wrong! Stairways can't sing!! Do you even know this song?                    Do you think we will have the taste of the times which were a long time ago!                    I have enough. Just enjoy your life and ignore the surroundings.                    Your email is f****!. All I want is another chance. Don't forget that I'm still single!                    You'd better start looking for a new romantic partner.
Email 2:
You need to do your job, "No Fear" and be cheerful! Stop shouting and screaming at people!! They can't sleep at night if they want to see what's going on in the world. It's good to wake them up. It can make them happy. It can make them laugh and it can make them more creative. 
I am very sorry. You shouldn't have seen my private life but at least you know where I live, what I do and how I feel. I think I should spend more time with you. I'm not telling you not to believe anything you see. But please trust me. I'm not someone who should get in trouble or get hurt because of a misunderstanding. 
I don't know how to say thank you but thank you very much anyway. I hope you will read this email again soon. And if you want to know more about me and
Email 3:
Thank you for your email. I was just checking my spam folder because I didn't receive a response. I read it now but I don't understand why I should delete my account if I have a right to complain about a product or service. That's what I want. I want to be able to say something. To complain or complain about something which I find annoying and can't deal with anymore. I want people to know that I am here and I have a problem with their product. So please read this again and don't delete my account. If you still want to get rid of me, at least send me a quick reply and tell me why you don't want me here.
output_text:
From: sarah.jones@email.com
To: mike.wilson@email.com
Subject: Re: Your music recommendation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:23
Body: Mike,

I don't understand why you're suggesting I listen to 'Stairway to Heaven' as some kind of solution to my situation. This isn't about reliving the past or trying to recapture old times. I'm going through a difficult period, and your response feels dismissive.

Yes, I'm still single, but that's not the point. I was hoping for actual support and understanding, not musical suggestions. Please take my concerns seriously.

Regards,
Sarah

---

From: mike.wilson@email.com
To: sarah.jones@email.com
Subject: Re: Re: Your music recommendation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 15:47
Body: Sarah,

I apologize if my previous email came across as insensitive. You're right - I should have been more supportive. I know you're going through a tough time, and I want to help. Perhaps we could spend more time talking about what's really bothering you?

I understand your frustration, but please know that I'm here to listen. Trust me when I say I want to help, not make light of your situation.

Let me know if you'd like to talk more about this.

Best,
Mike

---

From: sarah.jones@email.com
To: mike.wilson@email.com
Subject: Re: Re: Re: Your music recommendation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 16:32
Body: Mike,

I appreciate your response. I was checking my spam folder earlier because I hadn't heard back from you. I want to be clear - I need to be able to express my feelings without feeling dismissed. This isn't about deleting accounts or leaving; it's about being heard and understood.

Can we start over and have a real conversation about this?

Sarah

Hello Mr. Bae,                    I have a 28,000MT order for cargo from Singapore to China. I’m not sure what the best schedule will be, but let’s pick a port for loading and sail for 10 days and see what it comes up with. Could you calculate the cost of the voyage under FOB terms?                    Best regards,                    Ken
Email 2:
Thank you for your message about the cargo shipment. Please note that the vessel can pick up from Singapore to take the order to China at a very competitive rate. We do have a flexible voyage schedule so the date is not a constraint. If the cargo is in South Singapore, we are happy to prepare the vessel to sail on the same day. Kindly advise us your choices for the ports.                      Best regards,                      Ken

This email exchange took place between two different parts of a logistics system, one based in the US and the other based in Singapore. Their separate emails reinforce how each party within a supply chain makes a request and tries to determine how their request will be received by another party. In Email 1, Ken is requesting the transportation of cargo from Singapore to China. However, Ken doesn’t know how to price out the transportation; he therefore asks Mr. Bae to provide a

She would like to leave Singapore in two weeks and arrive in Amsterdam within a month. Kindly give me an idea about the cost to transport the cargo.                      Ken

Shelly

From: erik.zimmermann@shipping.com

Body: Dear Shelly,

It is much better to send 1,000MT of soybean oil from London to Sao Paulo. This way it is easier to handle. You can save 10,000 British pounds with this reduced volume.

Erik

Shelly

---

From: erik.zimmermann@shipping.com

Subject: Re: Soybean Oil Shipment Quote Request

Best regards,
Erik

input_text:
Email 1:
Morning Mr. Jones,                    Could you confirm whether your vessel can carry 6,500MT of steel from Tokyo to Cleveland? Also, I notice you've been quoted a $2,500 pilotage fee from Tsukaji to Tokyo. I notice this is below the usual charge of $2,750 but can I get a breakdown of the charges for Tsukaji so I can be sure?                    Thanks,                    Susan
Email 2:
Mr. Jones,
Thanks for your message. Unfortunately, I cannot carry 6,500MT. 
There's a bit more to it than the quote I gave you. The quota in Japan is just over 15,000MT and the port of Osaka holds the title of biggest port in the country. In fact, there are two other ports in the Kansai area (Hiroshima and Kobe) that are both bigger than Osaka. For our cargo to be loaded, it would have to be switched from Osaka and that would incur additional costs. Therefore, the whole quote you were given was subject to the eventual port of discharge being Osaka.

I'm sorry I cannot be of more help on the pilotage fee issue. I can only confirm that the pilotage fee has been quoted from Tsukaji as this is the port of call that's on the vessel's I.P. The
Email 3:
As I indicated before, the vessel cannot carry 6,500MT. Can I please also request a breakdown of the pilotage fees so I can fully understand the costs? I have contacted the port of Osaka regarding the ultimate port of discharge. Due to the current port congestion there, they do not hold any information that can determine when a berth will be available. I will ask them to confirm with the relevant operator and advise you immediately.
Kind regards,
Susan
Morning Susan,                          Could you please let me know what you have found out regarding your vessel's port of discharge and port congestion in Osaka. I'm just waiting to hear back from the operators but it seems that they've all been over-loaded with cargo so far this year. I would appreciate your comments ASAP.              Thanks,              Ian
Also, please could you provide me with a breakdown of pilotage fees. The carrier I use
output_text:
From: susan.carter@shipbroker.com
To: ian.jones@carrier.com
Subject: Steel Cargo Inquiry - Tokyo to Cleveland
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Morning Mr. Jones,

Could you confirm whether your vessel can carry 6,500MT of steel from Tokyo to Cleveland? Also, I notice you've been quoted a $2,500 pilotage fee from Tsukaji to Tokyo. I notice this is below the usual charge of $2,750 but can I get a breakdown of the charges for Tsukaji so I can be sure?

Thanks,
Susan

---

From: ian.jones@carrier.com
To: susan.carter@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Steel Cargo Inquiry - Tokyo to Cleveland
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:30
Body: Dear Susan,

Thanks for your message. Unfortunately, I cannot carry 6,500MT. 

Regarding the ports, there's a bit more complexity to consider. While the quota in Japan is just over 15,000MT, and while Osaka is a major port, both Hiroshima and Kobe in the Kansai area are larger. For our cargo to be loaded, it would need to be routed through Osaka, which would incur additional costs. Therefore, the quote provided was contingent on Osaka being the port of discharge.

Regarding the pilotage fee issue, I can only confirm that the fee has been quoted from Tsukaji as this is the port of call on the vessel's itinerary.

Best regards,
Ian

---

From: susan.carter@shipbroker.com
To: ian.jones@carrier.com
Subject: Re: Steel Cargo Inquiry - Tokyo to Cleveland
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:45
Body: Dear Ian,

As indicated before, the vessel cannot carry 6,500MT. Could I please request a breakdown of the pilotage fees so I can fully understand the costs? I have contacted the port of Osaka regarding the ultimate port of discharge. Due to the current port congestion there, they cannot determine when a berth will be available. I will ask them to confirm with the relevant operator and advise you immediately.

Kind regards,
Susan

---

From: ian.jones@carrier.com
To: susan.carter@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Steel Cargo Inquiry - Tokyo to Cleveland
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 08:30
Body: Morning Susan,

Could you please let me know what you have found out regarding your vessel's port of discharge and port congestion in Osaka. I'm just waiting to hear back from the operators, but it seems they've all been over-loaded with cargo so far this year. I would appreciate your comments ASAP.

Also, please could you provide me with a breakdown of pilotage fees.

Thanks,
Ian

Dear Mark,                    Could you please confirm your available slots for shipment from Philadelphia to Vado. Can you confirm rate if draft restrictions are an issue?                    Thank you,                    Tony
Email 2:
Hello,                       Please refer to <Attached document> for rate details. If you need any further assistance with this shipment, please do not hesitate to contact me.                    Thank you,                    On behalf of ALLEGHENY FREIGHT CORPORATION,                    Thomas, Jan
Email 3:
Dear John,                  Below is a list of rate options. Please provide me with the option which best meets your needs.                    If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me.                        Thank you,                    On behalf of TAHRIR SHIPPING,                     K.
You will notice in the above example that emails are exchanged using a clear subject line that contains details for the sender. The person who receives the message can read the message body to view the sender's question or response. The information in the subject line will also assist the recipient in answering the sender.
The message body is where you compose your email message.
Email 1: 
Dear [Recipient],
Please review <Attached document> for the proposed rate. If you have any questions, please contact me.
Regards,
[Sender]
Email 2:
This is a follow-up email to the attached email. Could you please confirm your rate
Email 4:
Below is a list of rate options. Please provide me with the option which best meets your needs.
If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me.
Regards,
[Sender]
Email 5:
Thank you for the confirmation of rate. Could you please verify the following:
1) Your rate.
2) Draft restrictions.

Email 1:
Dear Zane,                    We’re loading 7,000MT of vegetables from Dar es Salaam to Addis Ababa on Monday. Would it be possible to book 500MT of steel mill from Hamburg to Yokohama to release the vessel? How’s your destination demurrage?                    Best regards,                    Sarah
Email 2:
Dear Sarah,                      Thanks for your message. I’ll check on the destination demurrage. The Hamburg-Malaga-East Africa trade is highly competitive right now, with service owners wanting to keep their vessels busy. My principal still does not have any available steel mill.                   Best regards,                    Zane
Email 3:
Dear Sarah,                      I just received word from Hamburg. We will still be able to charter a steel mill on the Hamburg-Malaga-East Africa trade for this Monday. I see one departure from Hamburg and one from Malaga with a possible unloading location in Mombasa. We will reserve one vessel for this delivery.                   Best regards,                   Zane
Email 4:
Dear Zane, 
Sorry, my colleague requested this on the way to the meeting. Thanks for your help. 
Cheers, 
Mika
Email 5:
Dear Zane, 
I would like to have a quote for port and craneage for 100m3 of petrochemicals in Antwerp. Best, Justin
On Mon, 20 Mar 2017 11:08 am, Zane Hilbert <SALVATION@domain.com> wrote:
Dear Justin,
Our standard freight rate of EUR 145 is for a standard 10m3 container from Noyers to Antwerp. For this shipment, with a volume of 100 m3, the applicable freight rate would be EUR 17,500.  
Please inform me if you require any further information. 
Best regards,

Email 1:
Hi,                    Can I have an open slot to ship 8,400MT of methanol from India to Chile? We can come on at noon Sunday, with a laycan by Friday. If that sounds good, could you confirm my details and send a proforma invoice?                    Thanks,                    David
Email 2:
Hi David,                 Thanks for the enquiry. We can carry your cargo with a 7 day laycan from India to Chile.                     We will send a proforma invoice for 1 MT as a sample. If this sounds ok, please reply with your bank details and I will send the proforma.                     Thanks,                     Rahul

<Email 3>:
Hi Rahul,                 Our bank is IndusInd Bank Mumbai.                              Please send the proforma with the relevant info.                               Thanks,                               David
Email 3:
Hi Rahul,                 Our bank is IndusInd Bank Mumbai.                              Please send the proforma with the relevant info.                               Thanks,                               David

<Email 3>:
 Hi David,                 Sorry, IndusInd does not transfer dollars to India. Your FOB price of $350 is for rupees at INR 72, not dollars. Our 8,400 MT requirement would be $3.2 million at current rates.          We can ship 300 MT every two weeks for five months.                      I’ll convert these prices to rupees and send a proforma invoice.                  Best,                  Rahul
Email 4:
Hi David,                 Please see the attached proforma invoice for 300 MT of methanol at INR 71,249 per MT. We will ship your first load of methanol on 14 November 2018.                  Your next three loads will be due 28 November, 12 December, and 26 December 2018.                  Your total requirement will be 8,400 MT, which is worth $3.2 million at our current rates.                  I have enclosed a copy of your credit application form, which I will process to send you a formal letter of credit (LC).                  Please sign and return this form, and I will attach it to your LC for immediate processing.                  Best,                  Rahul

<Email 5>:
Hi Rahul,                 Thanks for your detailed reply.            We need to finalize the contract before the weekend, so we need to be sure

Rahul

Email 1:
Hello Ms. Jones,                    We’ve been told that a change in the state tax ruling in Alaska could affect our decision to ship ethanol there. Could you inform us how the pending decision will change your rate structure, and when we would see it in effect?                    Thanks,                    Oliver
Email 2:
Hello,                    Thank you for your recent letter and for providing the requested
information. We are pleased to share the attached information that addresses your inquiry and provides you with the necessary information to assist you with your concern.                    We hope this information was helpful, and if you have any further questions, please feel free to contact us at your earliest convenience. Thank you for your understanding and assistance.                    Sincerely,                    Mollie Harrison, Regional Manager Alaska State Tax Department

Please note that there are many ways to improve the clarity and accuracy of the communication you have just received.
The table of contents below summarizes some suggestions for improvement.
See additional information below for a list of sample improvement recommendations for this communication.

Improvement recommendations for this communication

1  Don't address other questions or issues. In response to "we've been told...," address the direct question (that is, do not
Email 3:
Alaska fuel tax on ethanol
As a company that is committed to helping Alaska achieve energy independence by supporting the development and production of cleaner, lower-emission fuels, we need your support to maintain our rates for ethanol and fuel additives shipped to Alaska.
Currently, we’re only able to offer discounted ethanol and additive rates due to the fact that the Alaska fuel tax does not differentiate between ethanol and petroleum-based products. However, this is set to change if a new state law is passed, which will allow ethanol to be taxed at 60 percent of the full price.
As a result, we would need to adjust our current rates and pass through a corresponding tax to ensure compliance with the new law. We can also help reduce your costs by absorbing the tax until June 30, 2013, but if the current rate remains unchanged, your fuel costs will increase significantly.
While we understand that a new
Email 4:
Alaska fuel tax on ethanol
Please find attached our email response from Pacific Ethanol, a supplier of ethanol and biodiesel to the Alaska state fuel tax department, regarding a change in the state tax ruling in Alaska which could affect our decision to ship ethanol there.
[Some companies place this as a hyperlink. This content may be on the corporate web site.]
output_text:
From: oliver.smith@pacificethanol.com
To: m.harrison@alaskatax.gov
Subject: Alaska State Tax Ruling - Ethanol Shipments
Timestamp: 2023-04-10 09:15
Body: Hello Ms. Harrison,

We've been told that a change in the state tax ruling in Alaska could affect our decision to ship ethanol there. Could you inform us how the pending decision will change your rate structure, and when we would see it in effect?

Thanks,
Oliver Smith

---

From: m.harrison@alaskatax.gov
To: oliver.smith@pacificethanol.com
Subject: Re: Alaska State Tax Ruling - Ethanol Shipments
Timestamp: 2023-04-11 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Smith,

Thank you for your inquiry regarding the pending tax ruling changes. I've attached the detailed documentation outlining the proposed changes to ethanol taxation in Alaska.

The key change is that ethanol will be taxed at 60% of the standard fuel tax rate, as opposed to the current structure where it's taxed equally with petroleum-based products. This change would take effect following the passage of the new state law.

Sincerely,
Mollie Harrison
Regional Manager
Alaska State Tax Department

---

From: oliver.smith@pacificethanol.com
To: stakeholders@pacificethanol.com
Subject: Fw: Alaska State Tax Ruling Impact
Timestamp: 2023-04-12 10:45
Body: As a company committed to supporting Alaska's energy independence through cleaner, lower-emission fuels, we need to address the upcoming tax changes.

The current situation allows us to offer discounted ethanol rates as the tax structure doesn't differentiate between ethanol and petroleum-based products. However, with the pending legislation, ethanol will be taxed at 60% of the full rate.

We can absorb the tax impact until June 30, 2023, but after that, we'll need to adjust our rates to reflect the new tax structure.

Best regards,
Oliver Smith

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Lie,                    We need a 3,400MT shipment of adhesives from Rotterdam to Lübeck in early October. Can you advise your earliest loading date?                    Best,                    Jan
Email 2:
Hello Jan,                    Thank you for your email. Our first 3,400MT loading is on October 4th, but it is a very tight window as that is a Monday and is usually our slowest week of the month.                    If you want to expedite it, we can try to send it on October 2nd or 1st, but the latter option is on our limited summer sailing schedule and will have to sail on a larger vessel than usual. The 2nd option is on our regular schedule and will have to use a vessel that is full and may have less throughput for you. However, we can still confirm loading dates by October 7th, so you will know for sure what you are getting into.                    Please confirm your choice so we can provide an invoice.                    Best,                    Lie Best

Message 1:

> Can you advise your earliest loading
output_text:
From: jan.hansen@tradeco.com
To: lie.best@shipline.nl
Subject: Adhesives Shipment Rotterdam-Lübeck Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-09-25 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Best,

We need a 3,400MT shipment of adhesives from Rotterdam to Lübeck in early October. Can you advise your earliest loading date?

Best regards,
Jan

---

From: lie.best@shipline.nl
To: jan.hansen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Adhesives Shipment Rotterdam-Lübeck Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-09-25 16:45
Body: Dear Jan,

Thank you for your email. Our first 3,400MT loading slot is available on October 4th, though this being a Monday makes it a challenging window due to typically reduced operations.

We can offer two alternative options:
1. October 1st - Using a larger vessel (subject to our limited summer schedule)
2. October 2nd - Regular schedule, but vessel will be operating at full capacity which may affect loading efficiency

We can confirm final loading dates by October 7th at the latest.

Please let me know which option you prefer so we can proceed with the invoice.

Best regards,
Lie Best

Best Regards,
Frank

### UPDATE:

Our customers frequently ask to be updated about a new order, as this often changes the equipment in the yard. The following sections are useful in order to achieve the goal of an informed client who is well prepared.

### After placing an order:

In order to obtain the equipment information, we first search our archives. To be able to search, the first three fields must be entered:

Field 1: Ship name: this is what most clients are familiar with. We enter all vessels (including those not yet built) in our database and we create a link between them and the order. As a result, the client receives the correct information about the order.

Hello Mr. Sonny,

Thank you for your inquiry. We got your email, and kindly we would like to talk over the matter more to see if we could work out.

This might be a bit surprising, but we do have agents in Tangshan too and our terminals are located in Dubai, UAE, and we also have our own ship. 

So we are more than happy to handle the bulk cargo shipment between China and the UAE, and we can get it processed by our ports system.

We are also more than happy to answer your questions as long as we know the detail information such as port of loading and unloading, loading or discharging port, cargo type, etc.

So please do let me know if you have more queries.

We would be honored if you can give us the opportunity to earn your business.

Regards,

<Manager>

We have already decided to book your service, please accept my words of apology for not giving you an opportunity to handle this business, I thought it was going to be a traditional (or institutional) tender. We will keep you updated on any development in the near future.

Manager
